editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

sp.l: Dares she despise me thus? me that with spoil
And hazardous exploits, full sixteen years
Have led (As handmaidens) fortune, victory
Whom the Maltezi call my servitors?
Tempests I have subdued, and fought 'em calm,
Out-lightened lightning in my chivalry;
Rid (Tame as patience) billows that kicked heaven,
Whistled enraged Boreas till his gusts
Were grown so gentle, that he seemed to sigh,
Because he could not show the air my keel,
And yet I cannot conquer her bright eyes,
Which though they blaze both comfort, and invite
Neither by force, nor fraud pass through her ear
(Whose guard it only blushing innocence)
To take the least possession of her heart,
Did I attempt her with a threadbare name — unapt with meritorious actions,
She might with colour disallow my suit:
But by the honour of this Christian cross
(In blood of infidels so often died)
Which mine own soul and sword hath fixed here
And neither favour, nor birth's privilege
Oriana shall confess, although she be
Valetias' sister our grand-master, here
The wages of scorned love is baneful hate,Enter Rocca.
And if I rule not her, I'll rule her fate.
Rocca, my trusty servant, welcome.

sp.speaker: Rocca.
sp.l: Sir,
I wish my news deserved it: hapless I
That being loved, and trusted, fail to bring
The loving answer that you do expect.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Why speak'st thou from me: thy pleased eyes send forth
Beams brighter than the star that ushers day,
Thy smiles, restore sick expectation.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: I bring you sir, her smiles, not mine.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Her smiles?
Why they are presents for King's eldest sons,
Great Solyman that wearies his hot eyes,
But to peruse his decked seraglio,
When from the number of his concubines
He chooseth one for that night, in his pride
Of them, wives, wealth, is not so rich as I
In this one smile, from Oriana sent.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Sir, fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: O Rocca! thou art wise,
And wouldst not have the torrent of my joy
Ruin me headlong; aptly thou conceivest
If one reviving smile can raise me thus,
What trances will the sweet words which thou bringest
Cast me into? I felt (My dearest friend,
No more my servant) when I employed thee
That knew'st to look, and speak as lovers should,
And carry faithfully thy masters sighs,
That it must work some heat in her cold heart,
And all my labours now come fraughted home
With ten fold prize.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Will you yet hear me?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Yes,
But take heed (Gentle Rocca,) that thou dost
Tenderly by degrees assault mine ears
With her consent, now to embrace my love,
For thou well knowest I have been so plunged, so torn
With her resolved reject, and neglect:
That to report her soft acceptance now,
Will stupefy sense in me, if not kill:
Why show'st thou this distemper?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Draw your sword,
And when I with my breath have blasted you,
Kill me with it:
I bring you smiles of pity, not affection:
For such she sent.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Oh! can she pity me?
Of all the paths lead to a woman's love,
Pity's the straightest.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Waken sir, and know
That her contempt (If you can name it so)
Continues still: she bids you throw your pearl
Into strong streams, and hope to turn them so,
Ere her to foul dishonour; write your plaints
In rocks of coral grown above the sea,
Them hope to soften to compassion,
Or change their modest blush to love sick pale,
Ere work her to your impious requests;
All your loose thoughts she chides you home again,
But with such calm behaviour, and mild looks,
She gentlier denies than others grant,
For just as others love, so doth she hate:
She says, that by your order you are bound
From marrying ever, and much marvels than
You would thus violate her and your own faith,
That being the virgin you should now protect,
Hitherto she professes she has concealed
Your lustful batteries, but the next she vows,
(In open hall, before the honoured cross
And her great brother) she will quite disclose
Calling for justice, to your utter shame.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Hence find the blackamoor that waits upon her,
Bring her unto me, she doth love me yet,
And I must her now, at least seem to do:
Cupid, thy brands that glow thus in my veins,
I will with blood extinguish — art not gone?
Shall my desires, like beggars, wait at door
Whilst any others revel in her breast?
Sweat on my spirits: know thou tricked up toy,
My love's a violent flood, where thou art fallen,Enter Astorius and Castriot.
Playing with which tide thou'dst been gently tossed,
But crossing it, thou art o'er whelmed, and lost.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Monsieur, good day.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Good morrow valiant knight,
What, are you for this great solemnity
This morn intended?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: What solemnity?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: The investing of the marshal Spaniard,
Peter Gomera, with our Christian badge.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: And young Miranda, the Italian,
Both which with wondrous prowess, and great luck
Have dared and done for Malta, such high feats,
That not one fort in it, but rings their names
As loud as any man's.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As any man's?
Why, we have fought for Malta.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Yes Mountferrat.
No bold knight ever passed you: but we wear
The dignity of Christians on our breasts,
And have a long time triumphed for our conquests;
These conquered a long time, not triumphed yet;

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Astorius, you are a most indulgent knight,
Detracting from yourself, to add to others,
You know this title is the period
To all our labours, the extremity
Of that tall pyramid, where honour hangs,
Which we with sweat and agony have reached,
And should not then so easily impart
So bright a wreath to every cheap desert.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: How is this French man changed Astorius?
Some sullen discontent possesses him,
That makes him envy, what he heretofore
Did most ingenuously but emulate.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: O furious desire, how like a whirlwind
Thou hurriest me beyond mine honour's point?
Out of my heart, base lust, or heart, I vow
Those flames that heat thee thus, I'll burn thee in.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Do 'Ye observe him?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: What news of the Dane,
That valiant captain Norandine?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: He fights kill,
In view oth' town; he plays the devil with 'em,
And they the turks with him.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: They're well met then, 'twere sin to sever.
Pish — woman. — memory —
Would one of ye would eave me:

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Six fresh galleys
I in st. Angelo from the promontory
This morn descried, making a girdle for him,
But our great master doth intend relief
This present meeting: will you walk along?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Hunch — I have read ladies enjoyed, have by
The gulfs of worthiest men, buried their names,
Their former valour, bounty, beauty, virtue,
And sent 'em stinking to untimely graves.
I that cannot enjoy, by her disdain,
Am like to prove as wretched; woman then
Checking or granting, is the grave of men.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: He's saying of his prayers sure.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Will you go sir?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I cry you mercy: I am so transported
(Your pardon, noble brothers) with a business
That doth concern all Malta, that I am
(Anon you'll hear't) almost blind, and deaf.
Lust neither sees nor hears ought but itself:
But I will follow instantly: your cross.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Not mine.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Nor mine: 'tis yours.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Cast. Good morrow brother. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: White innocent sign, that dost abhor to dwell
So near the dim thoughts of this troubled breast,
And grace these graceless projects of my heart. Enter Zanthia alias Abdella. Zan. with 2 letters.
Yet I must wear thee to protect my crimes,
If not for conscience, for hypocrisy,
Some churchmen so wear cassoks: o my
My pearl, that scorns a stain! I much repent
All my neglects: let me Ixion like,
Embrace my black cloud since my Juno is
So wrathful, and averse; thou art more soft
And full of dalliance than the fairest flesh,
And far more loving.

sp.speaker: Zan
sp.l: Ay, you say so now,
But like a property, when I have served
Your turns, you'll, cast me off, or hang me up
For a sign, somewhere.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: May my life then forsake me
Of my expected bliss, be cast to hell.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: My tongue sir, cannot lisp to meet you so,
Nor my black cheek put on a feigned blush,
To make me seem more modest than I am.
This groundwork, will not bear adulterate red,
Nor artificial white, to cozen love.
These dark locks, are not purchased, nor these teeth,
For every night, they are my bedfellows;
No bath, no blanching water, smoothing oils,
Doth mend me up; and yet Mountferrat, know,
I am as full of pleasure in the touch
As ere a white faced puppet of 'em all,
Juicy, and firm; unfledge 'em of their tires,
Their wires, their partlets, pins, and periwigs,
And they appear like bald coots, in the nest;
I can as blithely work in my love's bed,
And deck thy fair neck, with these jetty chains,
Sing thee asleep, being wearied, and refreshed,
With the same organ, steal sleep off again.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: O my black swan, silkner than signets plush,
Sweeter then is the sweet of pomander,
Breathed like curled Zephyrus, cooling lymon-trees,
Straight as young pines, or cedars in the grove,
Quickly descend lovers best canopy,
Still night, for Zanthia doth enamour me
Beyond all continuance; perpetrate (Dear wench)
What thou hast promised, and I vow by heaven
Malta, I'll leave in it, my honours here,
And in some other country (Zanthia) make
My wife, and my best fortune.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: From this hope,
Here is an answer to that letter, which
I lately showed you sent from Tripoli,
By the great bassa, which importunes her
Love unto him, and treachery to the island,
Which will she undertake, by Mahomet
The Turk there vows, on his blessed Alcharon,
Marriage unto her: this the master knows,
But is resolved of her integrity
(As well he may) sweet lady yet for love,
For love of thee Mountferrat, (Oh! what chains
Of deity, or duty can hold love?)
I have this answer framed, so like her hand
As if it had been moulded of: returning
The basha's letter safe into her pocket;
What you will do with it, yourself best knows,
Farewell, keep my true heart, keep true your vows. Exit Zan.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Till I be dust, my Zanthia; be confirmed.
Sparrows, and doves, sit coupling twixt thy lips,
It is not love, but strong libidinous will
That triumphs o'er me, and to satiat that,
What difference twixt this Moor, and her fair dame?
Night makes their hews alike, their use is so,
Whose hand so subtle, he can colours name,
If he do wink, and touch 'em: lust being blind,
Never in women did distinction find.Exit
But i'faith dost thou think my lady was never in love?
I rather think she was ever in love: in perfect charity.
I mean, with all the world.
A most christian answer I promise you: but I mean in
Love with a man.

sp.p: With a man? what else? wouldst have her in love with a beast?

sp.l: You are somewhat quick: but if she were, it were no
Precedent; did, you never read of Europa the fair, that leapt
A bull, that leapt the sea, that swam to land, and then leapt her?
O heavens, a bull?
Yes, a white bull.
Lord, how could she sit him? where did she hold?
Why, by the horn: since which time, no woman (Almost) is
Contented, till she have a horn of her own, to hold by.
Thou art very knavish.

sp.p: And thou very foolish: but sirrah, why dost not thou marry?

sp.l: Because I would be no man's lookingglass?
As how? Oriana ready above

sp.p: As thus, there is no wife, if she be good, and true, will honour, and obey, but must reflect the true countenance of her husband upon him; if he look sad upon her, she must not look merrily upon him: if he look merrily, she must not sorrowfully, else she is a false glass, and fit for nothing but breaking; his anger must be her discontent; his pleasure, her delight: if he weep, she must cry: if he laugh, she must show her teeth; if he be sick, she must not be in health; if he eat caudles, she must eat pottage, she must have no proper passion of her own; and is not this a tyranny?

Yes, i'faith, marriage may well be called a yoke; wives then are but like superficial lines in geometry, that have no proper motion of their own, but as their bodies their husbands move; yet I know some wives, that are never freely merry, nor truly pleased, but when they are farthest of their husbands.
That's because the moon governs 'em which hath most light and shines brightest, the more remote it is from the sun; and contrary is more sullen, dim, and shows least splendour, when it is nearest.
But if I were to marry I would marry a fair effeminate fool.

sp.l: Why?
Because I would lead the blind whether I list.

sp.p: And I the wisest man I could get for money, because I had rather follow the clear-sighted: bless me from a husband that sales by his wife's compass?

sp.l: Why?

sp.p: Why, 'tis ten to one but she breaks his head in her youth, and when she is old she'll never leave till she has broke his back too —
sp.l: But what scurvy knight have you here in Malta, etc.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Hist, wenches: my lady calls, she's entering the terrace, to see the show.

sp.l: O black pudding.
My little labour in vain.

sp.p: But what scurvy knights have we here in Malta, that when they are dubbed take their oath of allegiance to live poor, and chastely ever after?
I'faith many knights in other nations (I have heard) are as poor as ours: marry where one of 'em has taken the oath of chastity, we want a new columbm to find out.

div.head: Scoena tertia.
div.stage: Enter (Above) Oriana, Zanchia, two gentlewomen, (Beneath) Valetta, Mountferrat, Astorius, Castorot, Gomera, Miranda, attendants of knights, etc.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Are you there lady?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Thou art a naughty man,
Heaven mend thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Our great meeting princely brothers,
Ye holy soldiers of the Christian cross,
Is to relieve our captain Norandine,
Now fighting for Valetta, with the Turk,
A valiant gentleman, a noble Dane
As ere the country bred, endangered now
By fresh supply of head-bound infidels.
Much means, much blood this warlike Dane hath spent
To advance our flag, above their horned moons,
And oft hath brought in profitable conquest:
We must not see him perish in our view:
How far off fight they?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, within a league.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis well: our next occasion of conventing
Are these too gentlemen, standing in your sight.
(Ye noble props of Malta) royally
Descended are they both, valiant as war,
Miranda, and Gomera, full ten years
They have served this island, perfected exploits
Matchless, and infinite, they are honest, wise,
Not empty of one ornament of man:
Most eminent agents were they in that slaughter
That great marvelous slaughter of the Turks,
Before st. elm, where five and twenty thousand
Fell, for five thousand of our Christians:
These ripe considerations moving us
(Having had your allowance on their worthies)
Here we would call 'em to our brotherhood;
If any therefore can their manners tax,
Their faith, their chastity, any part of life,
Let 'em speak now.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: None does.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: None can, great master.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The dignity then dignify, by them
Is their reward: tender Miranda first
(Because he is to succour Norandine)
Our sacred robe of knighthood, our white cross,
The holy cognizance of him we serve,
The sword, the spurs.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Grave, and most honoured master,
With humble duty, and my soul's best thanks
To you, and all this famous conventicle,
Let me, with modesty refuse acceptance
Of this high order: I (Alas) am yet
Unworthy, and uncapable of such honour,
That merit, which with favour you enlarge
Is far, far short, of this proposed reward.
Who take upon him such a charge as this,
Must come with pure thoughts, and a gathered mind
That time, nor all occasions ever may
After disperse, or stain; did this title here
Of knighthood, ask no other ornaments
Then other countries glittering show, poor pride,
A gingling spur, a feather, a white hand,
'A frizzled hair, powdered, perfumes, and lust,
Drinking sweet wines, surfeits, and ignorance,
Rashly, and easily should I venture on't,
But this requires another kind of man.

sp.speaker: Mount
sp.l: A stayed, and mature judgement; speak on sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: May it please you then to allow me some small time
To rectify myself, for that high seat,
Or give my reasons to the contrary.
Ith' mean space, to dismiss me to the aid
Of Norandine: my ships ride in the bay
Ready to disembogue, tackled, and manned
Even to my wishes.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: His request
Is fair, and honest.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: At your pleasure go.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I humbly take my leave of all: of you
My noble friend Mountferrat; gracious mistress,
O that auspicious smile doth arm your soldier,
Who fights for those eyes, and this sacred cross,
Can neither meet sad accident, nor loss.Exit

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: The mighty master of that livery,
Conduct thee safely to these eyes again.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Blows the wind that way?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Equally beloved,
Equally meriting, Gomera, you
Without excuse receive that dignity:
Which our provincial chapter hath decreed you.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Great master of Jerusalem's hospital,
From whence to Rhodes this blessed fraternity
Was driven, but now among the Maltois stands,
Long may it flourish, whilst Gomera serves it,
But dares not enter farther.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: This is orange.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What do ye object?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Nothing against it, but myself (Fair knights)
I may not wear this robe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Express your reasons;
Doth any hid sin gore your conscience?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Are you unsteadfast in religion?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Or do you intend to forsake Malta now,
And visit your own country, fruitful Spain.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Never good sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then explicate your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: This then: I should be perjured to receive it,
Once in Malita, your next city here,
When I was younger, read I the decrees
Touching this point, being ambitious then
To approach it once, none but a gentleman
Can be admitted.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That's no obstacle
In you.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I should be sorry, that were it
No married man.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: You never felt that yoke.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: None, that hath been contracted.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Were you ever?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Nor married, nor contracted, none that ever
Hath vowed his love to any woman kind,
Or finds that secret fire within his thoughts:
Here I am cast, this article my heart
Objects against the title of my fame,
I am in love; laugh not: though time hath set
Some wrinkles in this face, and these curled locks
Will shortly die into another hue,
Yet, yet I am in love: (I'faith you smile)
What age, what sex, or what profession
Divine, or humane, from the man that cries
For arms in the high way, to him that sings
At the high altar, and doth sacrifice.
Can truly say he knows not what is love?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis honestly professed; with whom Gomera?
Name the lady, that with all advantage
We may advance your suit.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: But will you sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now by our holy rock were it our sister:
Spaniard, I hold thee worthy, freely name her.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Be master of your word: it is she sir,
The matchless Oriana.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come down lady,
You have made her blush, let her consent, I will
Make good my oath.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Is't so? stay: I do love
So tenderly Gomera, your bright flame,
As not to suffer your perdition.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: What means Mountferrat?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: This whole auberge hathEn. guard
(A guard upon this lady) wonder not,
'Ta'en public notice of the bassa's love
Of Tripoli unto her, and consented
She should return this answer, as he writ
For her conversion, and betraying Malta,
She should advise him betray Tripoli,
And turning christian, he should many her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All this was so.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: How weakly does this court then
Send vessels forth to sea, to guard the land
Taking such special care to save one bark,
Or strive to add famed men unto our cloak,
When they lurk in our bosoms would subvert
This state, and us, presuming on their blood,
And partial indulgence to their sex?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who can this be?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Your sister, great Valetta,
Which thus I prove: demand the bassa's letter.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: 'Tis here, nor from this pocket hath been moved
Nor answered, nor perused by —

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Do not swear
Cast not away your fair soul, to your treason
Add not foul perjury: is this your hand?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: 'Tis very like it.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: May it please the master,
Confer these letters, and then read her answer,
Which I have intercepted; pardon me
Reverend Valetta, that am made the means
To punish this most beauteous treachery,
Even in your sister, since in it I save
Malta from ruin: I am bolder in't,
Because it is so palpable, and withal
Know our great master to this country firm.
As was the Roman Marcus, who spared not
As dear a sister public cause.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am amazed; attend me.

body.p: Let you forces by the next even be ready, my brother feasts, then; put in at st. Michael's, the ascent at that port is easiest; the keys of the castle, you shall receive at my hands: that possessed, you are lord of Malta, and may soon destroy all by fire, than which I am better, till I embrace you,

sp.l: From this time let me never read again.

sp.speaker: Gent. wit
sp.l: 'Tis certain her hand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This letter too
So close kept by herself, could not be answered
To every period thus, but by herself.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Sir, hear me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Peace, thou fair sweet bank of flowers,
Under whose beauty scorpions lie, and kill;
Wert thou a kin to me, in some new name
Dearer than sister, mother, or all blood,
I would not hear thee speak: bear her to prison,
So gross is this, it needs no formal course,
Prepare thyself, tomorrow thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I die a martyr then, and a poor maid,
Almost i'faith as innocent as born,
Thou knowest thou art wicked, Frenchman, heaven forgive thee. Ex.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: This scene is strangely turned.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet can nature be
So dead in me? I would my charge were off,
Mountferrat should perceive my sister had
A brother would not live to see her die
Unfought for; since the statutes of our state
Allow (In case of accusations)
A champion to defend a lady's truth.
Peter Gomera, thou hast lost thy wife,
Death pleads a precontract.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I have lost my tongue,
My sense, my heart, and every faculty:
Mountferrat, go not up: with reverence
To our great master, and this consistory
(I have considered it, it cannot be)
Thou art a villain, and a forger,
A bloodsucker of innocence, an hypocrite,
A most unworthy wearer of our cross;
To make which good take (If thou dar'st) that gage,
And armed at all points like a gentleman
Meet me tomorrow morning, where the master,
And this fraternity shall design, where I
Will cram this slander back into thy throat,
And with say swords point thrust it to thy heart,
The very nest where lust and slander breeds.
Pardon my passion: I will tear those spurs
Off from thy heels, and stick in thy front
As a marked villain.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: This I looked not for:
Ten times more villainy, I return my gage,
And crave the law of arms.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: 'Tis that I crave.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: It cannot be denied.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Do not I know
With thousand gifts, and importunacies
Thou often hast solicited this lady
(Contrary to thy oath of chastity)
Who ne'er disclosing this thy hot reigned lust,
Yet tender to prevent a public scandal,
That Christendom might justly have imposed
Upon this holy institution.
Thou now hast drawn this practice 'gainst her life
To quit her charity.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Spaniard, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: No more Gomora, thou art granted combat,
And you Mountferrat must prepare against
Tomorrow morning in the valley here
Adjoining to st. George's port: a lady
In case of life 'gainst whom one witness comes
May have her champion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And who hath most rightFlourish exit
With, or against our sister, speed in fight.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Rocca, the first news of Miranda service
Let me have notice of.

sp.speaker: Roc
sp.l: You shall: the Moor
Waits you without.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Admit her, ha, ha, ha.
O, how my fancies run at tilt! Gomera
Loves Oriana; she, as I should guess,
Affects Miranda; these are two dear friends,
As firm, and full of fire, as steel and flint.
To make 'em so now, one against the other: En. Zanthia
Stay, let me like it better, Zanthia;
First tell me this, did don Gomera use
To give his visits to your mistress?

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Yes, and Miranda too: but severally.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Which did she most apply to?

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.l: Faith to neither:
Yet infinitely I have heard her praise 'em both,
And in that manner, that were both one man
I think she was in love with't.
Another letter you must frame for me
Instantly, in your lady's character,
To such a purpose as I'll tell thee straight,
Go in, and stay me: go my tinderbox,
Cross lines I'll cross; so, so: my aftergame
I must play better: woman, I will spread
My vengeance over Malta, for thy sake:
Spaniard, Italian, like my steel and stone,
I'll knock you thus together, were ye out
To light my dark deeds, whilst I seem precise,
And wink to save the sparkles from mind eyes.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Norandine, Miranda, and soldiers and gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How is it sir?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pray set me down; I cool,
And my, wounds smart.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I hope yet
Though there be many, there's none dangerous.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I know not, nor I care not much, I got 'em,
Like a too forward fool; but I hope the surgeons
Will take an order I shall not leave 'em so
I make the rogues more work than all the island,
And yet they give me the hardest words for my money.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I am glad ye are so sprightly: ye fought bravely
Go call the surgeon's soldiers: wondrous nobly
Upon my life, I have not seen such valour,
Maintained so long, and to so large a ruin,
The odds so strong against ye.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I thank ye,
And thank ye for your help, your timely succour.
By th' mass, it came ith' nick sir, and well handled;
Stoutly, and strongly handled: we had ducked else,
My Turk had turked me else: but he has well paid for't.
Why what a sign for an almanac has made me?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I am glad to find ye here sir, of necessity
I must have come aboard else; and brave captain
We all joy much in your fair victory,
And all the island speaks your valour nobly.
Have ye brought the Turk in that ye took?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: He rides there.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: If he were out again, the devil should bring him.
Has truly circumcised me.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I have a business
Which much concerns ye, presently concerns ye;
But not this place nor people: pray ye draw off sir,
For 'tis of that weight to ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'll wait on ye,
I must crave leave a while: my care dwells with ye,
And I must wait myself.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Your servant sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Believe I shall, and what my love can minister;
Keep your stout heart still.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: That's my best physician.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And I shall keep your fame fair. Exit.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Ye are too noble.
A brave young fellow, of a matchless spirit;
He brought me off like thunder, charged, and boarded,
As if he had been shot to save mine honour:
And when my fainting men tired with their labour,
And lack of blood gave to the Turk assurance
The day was his; when I was cut in shreds thus,
And not a corn of powder left to bless us,
Then flew his sword in, than his cannon roared,
And let fly blood and death in storms amongst 'em.
Then might I hear their sleepy prophet howled too,
And all their silver crescents than I saw
Like falling meteors spent, and set for ever
Under the cross of Malta; death so wanton
I never looked upon, so full of revel. Enter surgeon
I will not be dressed yet: methought that fellow
Was fit for no conversation, nor no christian
That had not half his brains knocked out, no soldier.
O valiant young man, how I love thy virtue.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Pray ye sir be dressed, alas ye bleed apace yet.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: 'Tis but the sweat of honour (Alas) thou milksop,
Thou man of march-pain, canst thou fear to see
A few light hurts, that blush they are no bigger,
A few small scratches? get ye a caudle sirrah,
Your finger aches: and let the old wives watch thee:
Bring in the booty, and the prisoners;
By heaven I'll see 'em, and dispose 'em first,
Before I have a drop of blood wiped from me; go. Exeunt soldiers.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: You'll faint sir.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: No, ye lie sir, like an ass, sir;
I have no such pigs hurt in my belly.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: By my life captain
These hurts are not to be jested with.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: If thou hadst 'em:
They are my companions fool, my family;
I cannot eat nor sleep without their company.
Dost take me for saint Davy, that fell dead
With seeing of his nose bleed? Enter soldiers with booty.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Here they come sir:
But would you would be dressed.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pox: dress thyself first,
Thou faintest a great deal faster what's all this?

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: The money and the merchandise ye took sir.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: A goodly purchase: is it for this we venture
Our liberties and lives? what can all this do?
Get me some dozen surfeits, some seven fresh whores,
And twenty pot-alleys and to: and then I am virtuous.
Lay the knights part by, and that to pay the soldier:
This is mine own, I think I have deserved it:
Come, now look to me, and grope me like a chambermaid,
I'll neither start, nor speak; what's that i'th truss there?

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: 'Tis cloth of tissue sir, and this is scarlet.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I shall look redder shortly then, I fear me,
And as a captain ought, a great deal prouder.
Can ye cure me of that crack, surgeon?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Yes, when your suit's at pawn, sir.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: There's for your plaster.
A very learned surgeon: what's in that pack there?

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: 'Tis English cloth.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: That's a good wear indeed,
Both strong, and rich: but it has a virtue
A twang of the own country, that spoils all:
A man shall ne'er be sober in't: where are the gentlemen
That ventured with me, both their lives and fortunes?
Come forward my fair spirits; Norandine
Forgets his worth, when he forgets your valours.
You have lost an eye, I saw ye face all hazards:
You have one left yet, to choose your mistress.
You have your leg broke with a shot; yet sitting,
I saw you make the place good with your pike still.
And your hand's gone; a good heart wants no instruments;
Share that amongst ye: there's an eye, an arm,
And that will bear you up, when your legs cannot.
O where's the honest sailor? that poor fellow,
Indeed that bold brave fellow, that with his musket
Taught them new ways how to put their caps off;
That stood the fire of all the fight, twice blown,
And twice I gave him drowned: welcome ashore knave;
Give me thy hand, if they be not both lost: faith thou art welcome,
My tough knave welcome: thou wilt not shrink ith' washing.
Hold, there's a piece of scarlet, get thee handsome.
And this to buy thee buttons.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: Thank ye captain,
Command my life at all hours.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Thou durst give it.
You have deserved too.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: We have seen the fight sir.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Yes: coiled up in a cable, like salt eels;
Or buried low ith' ballast: do you call that fighting?
Where be your wounds? your knocks? your want of limbs rogues?
Art not thou he that asked the master-gunner
Where thou mightst lie safest? and he straight answered,
Put thy head in that hole new bored with a cannon,
For 'twas a hundred to one, another shot would not hit there:
Your wages you shall have, but for rewards
Take your own ways: and get ye to the taverns;
There, when ye are hot with wine 'mongst your admirers,
Take ships, and towns, and castles at your pleasures,
And make the great Turk shake at your valours.
Bring in the prisoners now my brave musulmans,
You that are lords oth' sea, and scorn us Christians,
Which of your mangy lives is worth this hurt here?
Away to prison with 'em, see 'em safe;
You shall find we have galleys too, and slaves too.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: What shall be done with this woman sir?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pox take her,
'Twas she that set me on to fight with these rogues,
That ring worm rot it: what can you do now
With all your paintings, and your pouncings lady,
To restore my blood again? you, and your Cupid
That have made a carbinado of me; plague take ye,
Ye are too deep ye rogue, this is thy work woman,
Thou lousy woman; death, you go too deep still.
The seeing of your simpering sweetness: — ye filly,
Ye tit, ye-tomboy, what can one nights gingling,
Or two, or ten, sweet heart, and o ▪ my dear chicken,
Scratching my head, or fumbling with my foremast,
Do me good now? ye have powdered me for one year,
I am in souse I thank ye; thank your beauty,
Your most sweet beauty: pox upon those goggles.
We cannot fight like honest men, for honour,
And quietly kill one another as we ought,
But in steps one of you; the devil's holiness
And you must have a dance: away with her,
She stinks to me now.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Shall I have her captain?

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Or I?

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: I'll marry her.

sp.speaker: 4 soldier
sp.l: Good captain, I.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: And make her a good christian; lay hands on her;
I know she's mine.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: I'll give my full share for her: have ye no manners
To thrust the woman so?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Share her among ye;
And may she give ye as many hurts as I have,
And twice as many aches.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.l: Noble captain,
Be pleased to free me from these soldier's wildness,
Till I but speak two words.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Now for your maidenhead,
You have your book, proceed.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.l: Victorious sir,
'Tis seldom seen in men so valiant,
Minds so devoid of virtue: he that can conquer,
Should ever know how to preserve his conquest,
'Tis but a base theft else. Valour's a virtue,
Crown of men's actions here; yours as you make it.
And can you put so rough a foil as violence,
As wronging of weak woman to your triumph?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Let her alone.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.l: I have lost my husband, sir;
You feel not that: him that I love; you care not:
When fortune falls on you thus, you may grieve too;
My liberty, I kneel not for; mine honour,
(If ever virtuous honour touched your heart yet)
Make dear, and precious, sir: you had a mother.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: The rougy thing speaks finely, neat: who took ye?
For he must be your guard.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.l: I wish no better,
A noble gentleman, and nobly used me,
They called his name Miranda.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: You are his then:
Ye have light upon a young man worth your service,
I free ye from all the rest: and from all violence;
He that doth offer't, by my head he hangs for't:
Go see her safe kept, till the noble gentleman
Be ready to dispose her: thank your tongue,
You have a good one, and preserve it good still:
Soldiers, come wait on me, I'll see ye paid all. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I knew ye loved her, virtuously ye loved her,
Which made me make that haste: I knew ye prized her
As all fair minds do goodness.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Good Astorius,
I must confess I do much honour her,
And worthily I hope still.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: 'Tis no doubt sir,
For on my life she is much wronged.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Very likely:
And I as much tormented I was absent.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: You need not fear, Peter gomera's noble,
Of a tried faith and valour.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This I know too:
But whilst was not there, and whilst she suffered;
Whilst virtue suffered, friend, o how it loads me!
Whilst innocence and sweetness sunk together,
How cold it sits here? if my arm had fought her,
My truth, though naked, stood against all treasons,
My sword here grasped, love on the edge, and honour,
And but a signal from her eye to seal it,
If then she had been lost; I brag too late,
And too much I decline the noble Peter.
Yet some poor service I would do her sweetness,
Alas she needs it, my Astorius,
The gentle lady needs it.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Noble spirit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And what I can: prithee bear with this weakness.
Often I do not use these women's weapons
But where true pity is. I am much troubled,
And something have to do, I cannot form yet.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I'll take my leave, sir, I shall but disturb ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And please you for a while: and pray to fortune
To smile upon this lady.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: All my help sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Gomera's old and stiff: and he may lose her,
The winter of his years and wounds upon him:
And yet he has done bravely hitherto;
Mountferrat's fury, in his heat of summer,
The whistling of his sword like angry storms,
Renting up life by th' roots, I have seen him scale
As if a falcon had run up a train,
Clashing his warlike pinions, his steeled cuirass,
And at his pitch inmew the town below him.
I must do something. Enter Collonna.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Noble sir, for heaven's sake
Take pity of a poor afflicted christian
Redeemed from one affliction to another.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Boldly you ask that, we are bound to give it.
From what affliction sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: From cold, and hunger:
From nakedness, and stripes.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A prisoner?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A slave, sir, in the Turkish prize, new taken;
That in the heat of fight, when your brave hand
Brought the Dane succour, got my irons off,
And put myself to mercy of the ocean.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And swom to land?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I did sir, heaven was gracious;
But now a stranger, and my wants upon me,
Though willingly I would preserve this life sir,
With honesty and truth; I am not looked on;
The hand of pity, that should give for heaven's sake,
And charitable hearts are grown so cold, sir,
Never remembering what their fortunes may be.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou sayst too true: of what profession art thou?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I have been better trained; and can serve truly,
Where trust is laid upon me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A handsome fellow;
Hast thou ere bore arms?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I have trod full many a march, sir,
And some hurts have to show: before me too, sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pity this thing should starve, or forced for want
Come to a worse end. I know not what thou mayst be.
But if thou thinkst it fit to be a servant,
I'll be a master, and a good one to thee,
If ye deserve, sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Else I ask no favour.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Then sir, to try your trust, because I like you,
Go to the Dane, of him receive a woman,
A Turkish prisoner; for me receive her,
I hear she is my prize: look fairly to her,
For I would have her know, though now my prisoner,
The Christians need no schoolmasters for honour.
Take this to buy thee clothes: this ring, to help thee
Into the fellowship of my house: ye are a stranger,
And my servants will not know ye else; there keep her,
And with all modesty preserve your service.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A foul example find me else: heaven thank ye.
Of captain Norandine?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: 'Tis done sir:
And may heavens goodness ever dwell about ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Wait there till I come home.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I shall not fail, sir. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Mountferrat with a letter, and Abdella.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: 'Tis strange it should be so, that your high mettle
Should check thus poorly: dully; most unmanly.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Thus leadenly?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: — take ye.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: At every childish fear? at every shadow?
Are you Mountferrat, that have done such deeds?
Wrought through such bloody fields, men shake to speak of?
Can ye go back? is there a safety left yet
But foreright? is not ruin round about ye?
Have ye not still these arms, that sword, that heart whole?
Is't not a man ye fight with, and an old man,
A man half killed already? Am not I here
As lovely in my black to entertain thee,
As high, and full of heat, to meet thy pleasures?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I will be alone.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Ye shall: farewell sir;
And do it bravely, never think of conscience:
There is none to a man resolved be happy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: No, most unhappy wretch, as thou hast made me
More devil than thyself, I am.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Alone,
And troubled too, I take it: how he starts?
All is not handsome in thy heart Mountferrat.
God speed ye sir, I have been seeking of ye:
They say you are to fight today.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Mir
sp.l: Nay nothing but good fortune to your sword, sir.
Ye have a cause requires it, the islands safety,
The orders, and your honours.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: And do you make a question
I will not fight it nobly?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ye dare fight,
Ye have, and with as great a confidence as justice,
I have seen ye strike as home, and hit as deadly.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Why are these question then?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'll tell ye quickly.
Ye have a lady in your cause, a fair one,
A gentler never trod on ground, a nobler.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Do ye come on so fast? I have it for ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The sun ne'er saw a sweeter.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: These I grant ye:
Nor dare I against beauty heave my hand up,
It were unmanly, sir; too much unmanly:
But when these excellencies turn to ruin,
To ruin of themselves, and those protect 'em;
When virtue's lost lust, and dishonour entered,
Loss of ourselves, and souls basely projected —

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Do you think 'tis so?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Too sure.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And can it be?
Can it be thought Mountferrat, so much sweetness,
So great a magazine of all things precious,
A mind so heavenly made, prithee observe me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I thought so to: now by my holy order,
He that had told me, (Till experience found it
Too bold a proof) this lady had been vicious —
I wear no dull sword sir, nor hate I virtue,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Against her brother? to the man has bred her?
Her blood and honour?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Where ambitious lust
Desires to be above the rule prescribed her,
Takes hold, and wins, poor chastity, cold duty,
Like fashions old forgotten, she flings behind her,
And puts on blood and mischief, death, and ruin,
To raise her new built hopes, new faith to fasten her:
Ma foy, she is as foul, as heaven is beauteous.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou liest; thou liest Mountferrat: thou liest basely.
Stare not, nor swell not with thy pride: thou liest;
And this shall make it good.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Out with your heat first,
Ye shall be fought withal.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: By — that lady,
The virtue of that woman, were all the good deeds
Of all thy families bound in one faggot,
From Adam to this hour, but with one sparkle
Would fire that wisp, and turn it to light ashes.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: O pitiful young man, stroke blind with beauty!
Shot with a woman's smile: poor, poor Miranda;
Thou hopeful young man once; but now thou lost man:
Thou naked man of all that we call noble,
How art thou cozened? didst thou know what I do,
And how far thy dear honour (Mark me fool)
Which like a father I have kept from blasting,
Thy tender honour is abused ▪ but fight first,
And then too late, thou shalt know all.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou liest, still.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Stay, now I'll show thee all, and then I'll kill thee.
I love thee so dear, time shall not disgrace thee.
Read that.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It is her hand: it is most certain;
Good angels keep me: that I should be her agent
To betray Malta, and bring her to the bassa,
That on my tender love lay all her project!
Eyes, never see again, melt out for sorrow,
Did the devil do this?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: No, but his dam did it,
The virtuous lady that you love so dear;
Come, will ye fight again?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, prithee kill me:
For heaven's sake, and for goodness' sake dispatch me,
For the disgrace' sake that I gave thee, kill me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Why, are ye guilty?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I have lived Mountferrat,
To see dishonour swallow up all virtue,
And now would die: by heavens eternal brightness,
I am as clear as innocence.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I knew it,
And therefore kept this letter from all knowledge,
And this sword from anger, ye had died else.
And yet I lie, and basely lie.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O virtue!
Unspotted virtue, whither art thou vanished?
What hast thou left to abuse our frailties
In shape of goodness?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Come, take courage, man,
I have forgiven and forgotten your rashness,
And hold you fair as light in all your actions,
And by my troth I grieved your love; take comfort,
There be more women.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And more mischief in 'em.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: The justice I shall do, to right these villains
Shall make ye man again: I'll strike it sure sir.
Come, look up bravely: put this puling passion
Out of your mind; one knock for thee Miranda,
And for the boy, the grave Gomera gave thee,
When she accepted thee her champion;
And in thy absence, like a valiant gentleman,
I yet remember it: he is too young,
Too boyish, and to tender, to adventure:
I'll give him one sound rap for that: I love thee,
Thou art a brave young spark.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Boy did he call me?
Gomera call me boy?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: It pleased his gravity,
To think so of ye then: they that do service,
And honest service, such as thou, and I do,
Are either knaves, or boys.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Boy, by Gomera?
How looked he when he said it? for Gomera
Was ever wont to be a virtuous gentleman,
Humane, and sweet.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Yes, when he will, he can be;
But let it go, I would not breed dissension;
'Tis an unfriendly office, and had it been
To any of a higher strain than you sir,
The well known, well approved, and loved Miranda,
I had not thought on't: 'twas haply, his haste too,
And zeal to her.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A traitor and a boy too?
Shame take me if I suffer't: puff: farewell love.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Ye know my business, I must leave ye sir,
My hour grows on a pace.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I must not leave you
I dare not, nor I will not, till your goodness
Have granted me one courtesy: ye say ye love me?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I do, and dear: ask, and let that courtesy
Nothing concern mine honour,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You must do it.
Or you will never see me more:

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: What is it?
It shall be great that puts ye of; pray speak it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pray let me fight today: good, dear Mountferrat,
Let me, and bold Gomera —

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Fie Miranda,
Do ye weigh my worth so little?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: On my knees,
As ever thou hadst true touch of a sorrow
Thy friend conceived, as ever honour loved thee.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Shall I turn recreant now?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis not thy cause,
Thou hast no reputation wounded in't,
Thine's but a general zeal: 'Death: I am tainted,
The dearest twin to life, my credit's murdered,
Baffled, and buoy,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I am glad ye have swallowed it,
I must confess I pity ye; and 'tis a justice,
A great one too, you should revenge these injuries:
I know it, and I know ye fit and bold to do it,
And man, as much as man may: but Miranda,
Why do ye kneel?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: By — I'll grow to the ground here,
And with my sword dig up my grave, and fall in't
Unless thou grant me: dear Mountferrat, friend,
Is any thing in my power, to my life, sir?
The honour shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I love ye dear,
Yet so much I should tender.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'll preserve all:
By — I will: or all the sin fall with me,
Pray let me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Ye have won: I'll once be coward
To pleasure you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I kiss your hands, and thank ye.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Be tender of my credit, and fight bravely.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Blow not the fire that flames.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I'll send mine armour,
My man shall presently attend ye with it,
For you must arm immediately, the hour calls,
I know 'twill fit ye right; be sure, and secret,
And last be fortunate; farewell; ye are fitted:
I am glad the load's off me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: My best Mountferrat. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Doctor, I will see the combat, that's the truth on't
If I had never a leg, I would crawl to see it.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You are most unfit, if I might council ye,
Your wounds so many, and the air —

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: The halter;
The airs as good an air, as fine an air;
Wouldst thou have me live in an oven?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Beside the noise, sir:
Which to a tender body.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: That's it, doctor,
My body must be cured with all: if you'll heal me quickly,
Boil a drum-head in my broth: I never prosper,
With knuckles o'veal, and birds in sorrel sops,
Caudles, and cullises; they wash me away
Like a horse had eaten grains: if thou wilt cure me
A pickled herring, and a pottle of sack, doctor,
And half a dozen trumpets.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Ye are a strange gentleman,

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: As ere thou knew'st: wilt thou give mean other glister
That I may sit cleanly there, like a French lady,
When she goes to a mask at court? where's thy hoboy?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I am glad ye are grown so merry. Enter Astor: and castr.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: We come to see you sir; and glad we are
To see you thus, thus forward to your health, sir.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I thank my doctor here.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Nay, thank yourself sir,
For by my troth, I know not how he's cured,
He never observes any of our prescriptions.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Give me my money again then, good sweet doctor,
Wilt thou have twenty shillings a day for vexing me.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: That shall not serve ye sir;Drums afar off, a low march.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Then forty shall sir,
And that will make ye speak well: hark the drums

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: They begin to beat to th' field: oh noble Dane,
Never was such a stake, I hope of innocence
Played for in Malta and in blood before.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: It makes us hang our heads all.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: A bold villain:
If there be treason in it: accuse poor ladies?
And yet they may do mischief to: I'll be with ye:
If she be innocent, I shall find it quickly,
And something then I'll say.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Come, lean on us, sir,

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I thank ye gentlemen: and dominae doctor,
Pray bring a little sneezing powder in your pocket,
For fear I sound when I see blood.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You are pleasant. Exeunt.

sp.p: Are the combatants come in? The scaffold set out and the stairs.

sp.l: Yes.
Make the field clear there.
That's done too.
Then to the prisoner: the grand master's coming,
Let's see that all be ready there.
Too ready.
How ceremonious our very ends are?
Alas, sweet lady,
If she be innocent,Flourish.
No doubt but justice will direct her championEnter Valetta: Norandine Ashor. Castriot: c.
Away: I hear 'em come:
Pray heaven she prosper.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Give captain Norandine a chair.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I thank your lordship.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sit sir, and take your ease: your hurts require it.
You come to see a woman's cause descried:
That's all the knowledge now, or name I have for her:
They say a false, a base, and treacherous woman,
And partly proved too.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pity it should be so:
And if your lordship durst ask my opinion,
Sure, I should answer no: so much I honour her:
And answer't with my life too: but Gomera
Is a brave gentleman; the other valiant,
And if he be not good, dogs gnaw his flesh off,
And one above 'em both will find the truth out.
He never fails, sir,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That's the hope rests with me.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: How nature, and his honour struggle in him!
A sweet, clear, noble gentleman. Within, make room there enter Oriana; ladies, executioner, Abdel; la: 1 guard.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Make room there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Go up: and what you have to say, say there,

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Thus I ascend: nearer I hope to heaven,
Nor do I fear to tread this dark black mansion:
The image of my grave each foot we move,
Goes to it still: each hour we leave behind us,
Knolls sadly towards it: my noble brother,
For yet mine innocence dares calls ye so,
And you the friends to virtue, that come hither,
The chorus to this tragic scene behold me,
Behold me with your justice, not with pity,
(My cause was never so poor to ask compassion,)
Behold me in this spotless white I wear,
The emblem of my life, of all my actions,
So ye shall find my story, though I perish:
Behold me in my sex, I am no soldier,
Tender, and full of fears our blushing sex is,
Unhardened with relentless thoughts; unhatched
With blood, and bloody practice: alas we tremble;
But when an angry dream afflicts our fancies,
Die with a tale well told: had I been practised,
And known the way of mischief, travelled in it,
And given my blood, and honour up to reach it,
Forgotten religion, and the line I sprung on,
O heaven, I had been fit then for thy justice,
And then in black as dark as hell, I had howled here.
Last, in your own opinions weigh mine innocence;
Amongst ye I was planted from an infant
(Would then if heaven had so been pleased, I had perished)
Grew up, and goodly, ready to bear fruit,
The honourable fruit of marriage:
And am I blasted in my bud with treason?
Boldly, and basely of my fair name ravished,
And hither brought to find my rest in ruin?
But he that knows all he that rights all wrongs,
And in his time restores, knows me: I have spoken.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If ye be innocent, heaven will protect ye,
And so I leave ye to his sword strikes for ye,
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: O that went deep: farewell dear brother,
And howsoe'er my cause goes, see my body
(Upon my knees I ask it) buried chastely;
For yet, by holy truth, it never trespassed.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Justice sit on your cause; and heaven fight for ye.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Two of ye gentlemen, do me but the honour
To lead me to her: good my lord, your leave too:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have it sir.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Give me your fair hands fearless,
As white as this I see your innocence,
As spotless, and as pure: be not afraid lady,
You are but here brought to your nobler fortune,
To add unto your life immortal story:
Virtue, through hardest things arrives at happiness,
Shame follow that blunt sword that loses you:
And he that strikes against you: I shall study
A curse or two for him: once more your fair hands,
I never brought ill luck yet; be fearless happy.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I thank ye, noble captain.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: So I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Call in the knights severally. Enter severally Gomera, and Miranda.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: But two words to my champion,
And then to heaven and him, I give my cause up:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Speak quickly: and speak short.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I have not much sir.
Noble Gomera, from your own free virtue,
You have undertaken here a poor maid's honour,
And with the hazard of your life: and happily
You may suspect the cause, though in your true worth
You will not show it, therefore take this testimony
(And as I hope for happiness, a true one)
And may it steel your heart, and edge your good sword,
Ye fight for her as spotless of these mischiefs,
As heaven is of our sins, or truth of errors,
And so defy that treacherous man, and prosper.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Blessing o'thy heart lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Give the signal to 'em. Low alarms.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: 'Tis bravely fought Gomera; follow that blows,
Well struck again boy: look upon the lady,
And gather spirit: brave again: lie close.
Lie close I say: he fights aloft, and strongly:
Close for thy life: a — of that fell buffet:
Retire, and gather breath: ye have day enough knights;
Look lovely on him lady: to't again now,
Stand, stand Gomera, stand: one blow for all now.
Gather thy strength together; God bless the woman:
Why, where's thy noble heart? heaven bless the lady.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O, oh!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She is gone, she is gone:

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Now strike it.
Hold, hold: he yields: hold thy brave sword, he's conquered:
He's thine Gomera, now be joyful lady:
What could this thief have done, had his cause been equal?
He made my heart strings tremble.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Off with his cask there;
And executioner, take you his head next.

sp.speaker: Abdel.
sp.l: O cursed fortune!

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Stay, I beseech ye sir, and this one honour
Grant me, I have deserved it, that this villain
May live one day, to envy at my justice,
That he may pine, and die before the sword fall.
Viewing the glory, I have won her goodness.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He shall, and you the harvest of your valour
Shall reap brave sir, abundantly.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I have saved her.
Preserved her spotless worth from black destruction,
Her white name to eternity delivered,
Her youth, and sweetness, from a timeless rain.
Now lord Valetta, if this bloody labour
May but deserve her favour.

sp.speaker: Mir,
sp.l: Stay and hear me first.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Of with his cask, this is Miranda's voice.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: 'Tis he indeed, or else mine eyes abuse me,
What makes he here thus?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: The young Miranda?
Is he mine enemy too?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: None has deserved her
If worth must carry it, and service seek her,
But he that saved her honour.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: That's I Miranda.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, no, that's I Gomera, be not so forward,
In bargain for my love, ye cannot cozen me.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I fought it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And I gave it: which is nobler?
Why every gentleman would have done as much
As you did: fought it: that's a poor desert, sir,
They are bound to that; but then to make that fight sure,
To do as I did, take all danger from it
Suffer that coldness, that must call me now
Into disgrace for ever, into pity.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I undertook first, to preserve from hazard.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And I made sure no hazard should come near her.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: 'Twas t defied Mountferrat.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Twas I wrought him,
You had had a dark day else; 'twas I defied
His conscience first, 'twas I that shook him there,
Which is the brave defiance.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: My life and honour
At stake I laid,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: My care; and truth lay by it
Lest that stake might be lost: I have deserved her,
And none but I; the lady might have perished,
Had fell Mountferrat struck it, from whose malice
With cunning, and bold confidence I catched it,
And 'twas high time, and such a service lady
For you, and for your innocence, for who knows not
The all devouring sword of fierce Mountferrat?
I showed ye what I could do, had I been spiteful
Or master but of half the poison he bears,
(Hell take his heart for't) and beshrew these hands madam,
With all my heart, I wish a mischief on 'em,
They made ye once look sad: such another fright
I would not put ye in, to own the island,
Yet pardon me, 'twas but to show a soldier,
Which, when I had done, I ended your poor coward.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Let some look out, for the base knightMountferrat.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I hope he's far enough if his man be trusty:
This was a strange misfortune; I must not know it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That most debauched knight! come down sweet sister.
My spotless sister; now, pray thank these gentlemen,
They have deserved both truly, nobly of ye.
Both excellently dear, both all the honour
All the respect and favour.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Both shall have it;
And as my life, their memories I'll nourish.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ye are both true knights, and both most worthy lovers,
Here stands a lady ripened with your service,
Young, fair, and (Now I dare say) truly honourable:
'Tis my will she shall marry: marry now,
And one of you (She cannot take more nobly) your deserts
Begotten this will, and bred it; both her beauty
Cannot enjoy: dare ye mark me your umpler?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Mir. With all our souls.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He must not then be angry
That loses her.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: O, that were sir, unworthy,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A little sorrow he may find.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis manly.
Gomera, you are a brave accomplished gentleman
A braver nowhere lives then is Miranda,
In the white way of virtue, and true valour.
Ye have been a pilgrim long: yet no man farther
Has trod those thorny steps then young Miranda,
You are gentle: he is gentleness self: experience
Calls you her brother; 'tis his hopeful heir.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: The young man now, and 't be thy will.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your hand sir;
You undertook first: nobly undertook,
This lady's cause: you made it good, and fought it
You must be served first: take her, and enjoy her,
I give her to you: kiss her; are you pleased now?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: My joy's so much I cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, fairest sir;
You must not be displeased: you break your promise.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I never grieved at good, nor dare I now sir,
Though something seem strange to me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have provided
A better match for you: more full of beauty,
I'll wed ye to our order: there's a mistress,
Whose beauty never decays: time stands below her:
Whose honour ermin-like, can never suffer,
Spot, or black soil; whose eternal issue
Fame brings up at her breasts, and leaves 'em sainted.
Her you shall marry.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I must humbly thank ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Saint Thomas fort, a charge of no small value
I give ye too, in present, to keep waking
Your noble spirits; and to breed ye pious,
I'll send ye a probation robe; wear that
Till ye shall please to be our brother: how now?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Mountferrat's fled sir. Enter Actorius.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Let him go a while
Till we have done these rites, and seen these coupled:
His mischief now lies open: come all friends now.
And so let's march to th' temple, sound those instruments,
That were the signal to a day of blood;
Evil beginning hours may end in good. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Come, we'll have wenches man, and all brave things.
— let her go: we'll want no mistresses,
Good swords, and good strong armours.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Those are best captain.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: And fight till Queens be in love with us, and run
I'll see ye at the fort within these two days,
And let's be merry prithee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: By that time I shall.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Why that's well said: I like a good heart truly.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Norandine, and servant, corporal and soldiers above.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The day's not yet broke sir.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: 'Tis the cooler riding,
I must go see Miranda: bring my horse
Round to the South port: I'll out here at the beach
And meet ye at the end oth' sycamores,
'Tis a sweet walk, and if the wind be stirring
Serves like a fan to cool. Corporal and watch above singing.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Which walk?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Why that sir,
Where the fine city dames meet to make matches.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Speed ye then: what mirth is this?
The watches are not yet discharged, I take it:
These are brave careless rogues; I'll hear the song out
And then I'll fit ye for't, merry companions:
Here's notable order, now for a trick to tame ye —
Owgh, owgh.

sp.speaker: 1. Wat.
sp.l: Hark, hark, what's that below us? who goes there?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Owgh, owgh, owgh.

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.l: 'Tis a bear broke loose: pray call the corporal.

sp.speaker: 1 W.
sp.l: The dutchman's huge fat sow.
I see her now, and five fine pigs.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Owgh, owgh.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: 1 W.
sp.l: Here's the great fat sow, corporal.
The Dutchman's sow, and all the pigs, brave fat pigs,
You have been wishing long she would break loose.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Owgh, owgh.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: 'Tis she indeed, there's a white pig now sucking,
Look, look, do you see it sirs.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.l: Yes, very well sir.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: A notable fat whoreson; come two of ye.
Go down with me, we'll have a tickling breakfast.

sp.speaker: 2 W.
sp.l: Let's eat 'em at the cross.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: There's the best liquor.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I'll liquor some of ye, ye lazy rogues,
Your minds are of nothing but eating and swilling:
What a sweet beast they have made of me? A sow?
Hog upon hog? I hear 'em come. Enter Cor. below and watch.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Go softly, and fall upon 'em finely, nimbly.

sp.speaker: 1 W.
sp.l: Bless me.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: 1 W.
sp.l: O the devil!
The devil, as high as a steeple.

sp.speaker: 2 W.
sp.l: There he goes corporal,
His feet are cloven too.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Stand, stand I say: death 'How I shake?
Where be your muskets?

sp.speaker: 1 W.
sp.l: There's no good of them:
Where be our prayers, man?

sp.speaker: 2 W.
sp.l: Lord, how he stalks: speak to him corporal.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Why, what a devil art thou.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Owgh owgh.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: A dumb devil.
The worst devil that could come, a dumb devil,
Give me a musket; he gathers in to me,
I'th name of — speak what art thou? — speak devil,
Or I'll put a plumb in your belly.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Owgh, owgh, owgh.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Fie, fie, in what a sweat I am! Lord bless me,
My muskets gone too, I am notable to stir it.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Who goes there? stand speak.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Sure I am enchanted.
Yet here's my halbert still: nay, who goes there sir,
What have I lost myself? what are ye?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: The guard.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Why what are we then: he's not half so long now.
Nor he has no tail at all, I shake still damnably.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: The word.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: 'Have mercy on me, what word does he mean,
Prithee devil if thou beest the devil,
Do not make an ass of me; for I remember yet
As well as I am here, I am the corporal,
I'll lay my life on't devil.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Thou art damned:

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: That's all one: but am not I the corpo all?
I would give a thousand pound to be resolved now,
Had not I soldiers here?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: No, not a man,
Thou art deboshed, and cozened.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: That may be,
It may be I am drunk; lord, where have I been?
Is not this my halbert in my hand?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: No, 'tis a maypole.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Why then I know not who I am, nor what,
Nor whence I come.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Ye are an errand rascal;
You corporal of a watch.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: 'Tis the dane's voice: you are no devil then.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: No, nor no sow, sir.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Of that I am right glad sir,
I was never so frighted in my life, as I am a soldier.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Tall watchmen,
A guard for a goose, you sing away your centuries.
A careful company: let me out oth' port here,
I was a little merry with your worships:
And keep your guards strong, though the devil walk.
Hold, there's to bring ye into your wits again.
Go off no more to hunt pigs: such another trick
And you will hunt the gallows.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Pray sir pardon us:
And let the devil come next, I'll make him stand
Or make him stink.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Do do your duty truly.
Come let me cut, and come away: no more rage. Exe.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Abdella with a letter, and Rocca.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Write thus to me? he hath fearfully, and basely
Betrayed his own cause; yet to free himself
He now ascribes the fault to me.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: I know not.
What he hath done: but what he now desires,
His letters have informed you.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Yes, he is
Too well acquainted with the power he holds,
Over my mad affections: I want time
To write: but pray you tell him, if I were
No better steeled in my strong resolutions
Then he hath shown himself in his; or thought
There was a hell hereafter, or a heaven,
But in enjoying him, I should stick here,
And move no further: bid him yet take comfort;
For something I will do, the devil would quake at,
But I'll untie this nuptial knot of love,
And make way for his wishes: in the mean time
Let him lie close, for he is strictly sought for,
And practise to love her, that for his ends
Scorns fear and danger. Enter Oriana, and Velleda.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: All this I will tell him. Exit Rocca.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Do so: farewell. My lady, with my fellow,
So earnest in discourse! whate'er it be
I'll second it.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: He is such a noble husband,
In every circumstance, so truly loving,
That I might say, and without flattery, madam
The sun sees not a lady but yourself
That can deserve him.

sp.speaker: Abd
sp.l: Of all men I say
That dare (For 'tis a desperate adventure)
Wear on their free necks the sweet yoke of woman,
(For they that do repine, are no true husbands)
Give me a soldier.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Why, are they more loving
Than other men?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: And love too with more judgement;
For, but observe, you courtier is more curious
To set himself forth richly then his lady;
His baths, perfumes, nay paintings too, more costly
Than his frugality will allow to her,
His clothes as chargeable; and grant him but
A thing without a beard, and he may pass
At all times for a woman, and with some
Have better welcome: now, your man of lands
For the most part is careful to manure them,
But leaves his lady fallow; your great merchant
Breaks oftener for the debt he owes his wife,
Then with his creditors; and that's the reason
She looks elsewhere for payment: now your soldier —

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: I marry, do him right.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: First, who has one,
Has a perpetual guard upon her honour;
For while he wears a sword, Isander herself
Dares not bark at it: next, she sits at home,
Like a great Queen, and tends him forth to fetch in
Her tribute from all parts; which being brought home,
He lays it at her feet, and seeks no further
For his reward, than what she may give freely,
And with delight too, from her own exchequer
Which he finds ever open.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Be more modest.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Why, we may speak of that we are glad to taste of,
Among ourselves i mean.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Thou talkest of nothing.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Of nothing madam? You have found it something;
Or with the raising up this pretty mount here,
My lord hath dealt with spirits. Enter Gomera.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Two long hours absent?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Thy pardon, sweet: I have been looking on
The prize that was brought in by the brave Dane,
The valiant Norandine, and have brought something,
That may be thou wilt like of; but one kiss,
And then possess my purchase: there's a piece
Of cloth of tissue) this of purpler velvet,
And as they swear of the right Tyrian dye,
Which others hear but weakly counterfeit:
If they are worth thy use, wear them; if not,
Bestow them on thy women.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Here's the husband.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: While there is any trading o the sea
Thou shalt want nothing; 'tis a soldier's glory,
However he neglect himself, to keep
His mistress in full lustre.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: You exceed sir.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Yet there was one part of the prize disposed of.
Before I came, which I grieve that I missed of,
Being almost assured, it would have been
A welcome present.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Pray you say, what was it?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: A Turkish captive of incomparable beauty,
And without question, in her country noble;
Which as companion to thy faithful noble;
I would have given thee for thy slave.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: But was she
Of such an exquisite form?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Most equisite.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: And well descended?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: So the habit promised,
In which she was taken.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Of what years?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: 'Tis said
A virgin of fourteen.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I pity her,
And wish she were mine, that I might have the means
To entertain her gently.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: She's now Miranda's,
And as I have heard, made it her suit to be so.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Miranda; s? than her fate deserves not pity,
But envy rather.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Envy Oriana?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Yes, and their envy that live free.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Why, she is fallen into the hands of one,
So full of that, which in men we style goodness,
That in her being his slave, she is happier far
Than if she were confirmed the sultan's mistress.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Miranda is indeed a gentleman
Of fair desert, and better hopes, but yet
He hath his equals.

sp.speaker: 0ri.
sp.l: Where? I would go far,
As I am now, though much unfit for travails,
But to see one that without injury
Might be put in the scale, or parallelled,
In any thing that's noble, with Miranda;
His knowledge in all services of war,
And ready courage, to put into act
That knowing judgement, as you, are a soldier
You best may speak of. Nor can you deliver,
Nor I hear with delight, a better subject.
And heaven did well, in such a lovely feature
To place so chaste a mind; for he is of
So sweet a carriage, such a winning nature,
And such a bold, yet well disposed behaviour;
And to all these, has such a charming tongue,
That if he would serve under love's fresh colours,
What monumental trophies might he raise,
Of his free conquests, made in ladies' favours?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Yet you didst, resist him, when he was
An earnest suitor to you.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Yes I did;
And if I were again sought to, I should;
But must ascribe it rather to the fate
That did appoint me yours, than any power
Which I can call mine own.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: E'en so?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Thanks fortune,
The plot I had to raise in him, doubts of her,
Thou hast effected.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I could tell you too,
What cause I have to love him, with what reason.
In thankfulness, he may expect from me,
All due observance; but I pass that, as
A benefit, for which in my behalf
You are his debtor.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: I perceive it takes,
By his changed looks.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: He is not in the city?
Is he my lord?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Who lady?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Why Miranda,
Having you here, can there be any else
Worth my enquiry?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: This is somewhat more.
Then love to virtue,

sp.speaker: Ori:
sp.l: Faith when he comes hither
(As sometimes, without question you shall meet him)
Invite him home.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: To what end?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: To dine with us,
Or sup.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: And then to take a hard bed with you:
Mean you not so?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: If you could win him to it,
▪ 'twould be the better; for his entertainment,
Leave that to me, he shall find noble usage,
And from me a free welcome.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Have you never
Heard of a Roman lady (Oriana)
Remembered as a precedent for matrons,
(Chaste ones, I pray you understand) whose husband
Taxed for his sour breath by his enemy,
Condemned his wife, for not acquainting him
With his infirmity?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: 'Tis a common one;
