Her answer was, having kissed none but him,
She thought it was a general disease
All men were subject to; but what infer you
From that my lord?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Why, that this virtuous lady
Had all her thoughts so fixed upon her lord,
That she could find no spare time to sing praises
Of any other; nor would she employ
Her husband (Though perhaps in debt to years
As far as I am) for an instrument
To bring home younger men that might delight her
With their discourse, or —

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What my lord?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Their persons,
Or if I shouted speak plainer —

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: No it needs not,
You have said enough to make my innocence know
It is suspected.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: You betray yourself
To more than a suspicion; could you else
To me that live in nothing but love to you
Make such a gross discovery, that your lust
Had sold that heart I thought mine, to Miranda?
Or rise to such a height in impudence,
As to presume to work my yielding weakness
To play for your bad ends, to my disgrace
The wittal, or the pander?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Do not study
To print more wounds, (For that were tyranny)
Upon a heart that is pierced through already.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Thy heart? thou hast pierced through mine honour false one,
The honour of my house, fool that I was,
To give it up to the deceiving trust
Of wicked woman: for thy sake, vild creature,
For all I have done well in, in my life,
I have digged a grave, all buried in a wife;
For thee I have defied my constant mistress,
That never failed her servant, glorious war;
For thee, refused the fellowship of an order
Which princes through all dangers have been proud
To fetch as far as from Jerusalem:
And am I thus rewarded?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: By all goodness,
You wrong my lady, and deserve her not,
When you are at your best: repent your rashness,
'Twill show well in you.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Do, and ask her pardon.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: No, I have lived too long, to have my faith
(My tried faith) called in question, and by him
That should know true affection is too tender
To suffer an unkind touch, without ruin;
Study ingratitude, all, from my example;
For to be thankful now, is to be false.
But be it so, let me die, I see you wish it;
Yet dead for truth, and pities sake, report
What weapon you made choice of, when you killed me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: She faints,

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: What have ye done?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: My last breath cannot
Be better spent, than to say I forgive you;
Nor is my death untimely, since with me
I take along, what might have been hereafter
In scorn delivered for the doubtful issue
Of a suspected mother.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: O, she's gone.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: For ever gone. Are you a man?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I grow here.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Open her mouth, and pour this cordial in it;
If any spark of life be unquenched in her,
This will recover her.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: 'Tis all in vain,
She's stiff already: live I, and she dead?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: How like a murderer I stand? look up,
And hear me curse myself, or but behold
The vengeance I wilt take for't Oriana,
And then in peace forsake me: jealousy,
Thou loathsome vomit of the fiends below,
What desperate hunger made me to receive thee
Into my heart, and soul? I let thee forth,
And so in death find ease; and does ray fault then
Deserve no greater punishment? no, I'll live
To keep thee for a fury ▪ to torment me,
And make me know what hell is on the earth:
All joys and hopes forsake me; all men's malice,
And all the plagues they can inflict, I wish it
Fall thick upon me: let my tears be laughed at,
And may my enemies smile to hear me groan,
And dead, may I be pitied of none. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray you sir why was the ordnance of the fort discharged so suddenly?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: 'Twas the governors pleasure,
In honour of the Dane, a custom used,
To speak a soldier's welcome.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis a fit one:
But is my master here too?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Three days since.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Might I demand without offence, so much,
Is't pride in him (However now a slave)
That I am not admitted to his presence?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: His courtesy to you, and to mankind
May easily resolve you, he is free
From that poor vice which only empty men
Esteem a virtue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's the reason then,
As you imagine, sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Why I will tell you;
You are a woman of a tempting beauty,
And he, however virtuous, as a man
Subject to humane frailties; and how far
They may prevail upon him, should he see you,
He is not ignorant: and therefore chooses,
With care t'avoid the cause that may produce
Some strange effect, which will not well keep rank
With the rare temperance, which is admired
In his life hitherto.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This much increases
My strong desire to see him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: It should rather
Teach you to thank the prophet that you worship,
That you are such a man's, who though he may
Do any thing which youth and heat of blood
Invites him to, yet dares not give way to them:
Your entertainment's noble, and not like
Your present fortune; and it all those tears
Which made grief lovely in you, in the relation
Of the sad story, that forced me to weep too,
Your husband's hard fate were not counterfeit;
You should rejoice that you have means to pay
A chaste life to his memory, and bring to him
Those sweets, which while he lived he could not taste of:
But if you wantonly bestow them on
Another man, you offer violence
To him, though dead; and his grieved spirit will suffer
For your immodest looseness.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why, I hope sir,
My willingness to look on him, to whom
I owe my life and service, is no proof
Of any unchaste purpose.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: So I wish too,
And in the confidence it is not, lady,
I dare the better tell you he will see you
This night, in which by him I am commanded,
To bring you to his chamber; to what end
I easily should guess, were I Miranda;
And therefore, though I can yield little reason,
(But in a general love to women's goodness)
Why I should be so tender of your honour,
I willingly would bestow some counsel of you,
And would you follow it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Let me first hear it,
And then I can resolve you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My advice then
Is, that you would not, (As most ladies use
When they prepare themselves for such encounters)
Study to add, by artificial dressings
To native excellence; yours (Without help)
But seen as it is now, would make a hermit
Leave his death's head, and change his after hopes
Of endless comforts for a few short minutes
Of present pleasures; to prevent which, lady,
Practice to take away from your perfections,
And to preserve your chastity unstained,
The most deformed shape that you can put on
To cloud your bodies fair gifts, or your minds,
(It being laboured to so chaste an end)
Will prove the fairest ornament.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To take from
The workmanship of heaven, is an offence
As great, as to endeavour to add to it;
Of which I'll not be guilty: chastity
That lodges in deformity, appears rather
A mulct imposed by nature, than a blessing;
And 'tis commendable only when it conquers,
Though ne'er so oft assaulted, in resistance:
For me, I'll therefore so dispose myself,
That if I hold out, it shall be with honour;
Or if I yield, Miranda shall find something
To make him love his victory. Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: With what cunning
This woman argues for her own damnation?
Nor should I hold it for a miracle,
Since they are all born sophisters, to maintain
That lust is lawful, and the end and use
Of their creation: would I never had
Hoped better of her; or could not believe,
Though seen the mine, I must ever grieve. Exit.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Miranda, Norandine, servants with lights.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I'll see you in your chamber. A table out tow stools.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pray ye no farther:
It is a ceremony I expect not,
I am no stranger here, I know my lodging,
And have slept soundly there, when the Turk's cannon
Played thick upon't: oh 'twas royal music,
And to procure a sound sleep for a soldier,
Worth forty of your fiddles. As you love me
Press it no further.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You will overcome.
Wait on him carefully.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I have taken since supper
A rouse or two too much, and by —
It warms my blood.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You'll sleep the better for't.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: — on't, I should, had but I a kind wench
To pull my boot-hose off, and warm my nightcap,
There's no charm like it: I love old Adam's way;
Give me a diligent eve, to wait towards bedtime,
Hang up your smooth chin page: and now I think on't,
Where is your Turkish prisoner?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: In the castle,
But yet I never saw her.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Fie upon you:
See her for shame? or, hark ye, if you would
Perform the friends part to me, the friend's part,
It being a fashion of the last edition,
Far from panderism, now send her to me;
You look strange on't, no entertainments perfect
Without it on my word; no livery like it;
I'll tell her, he looks for it as duly
As for his fee; there's no suit got without it,
Gold is an ass to't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Go to bed, to bed.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Well, if she come, I doubt not to convert her,
If not, the sin lie on your head.
Good nightExit Nor. and servants.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There you shall found hint lady: you know what I have said,
And if you please you may make use.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No doubt sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: From hence I shall hear all.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come hither young one.
Beshrew my heart, a handsome wench: come nearer,
A very handsome one: do not you grieve, sweet,
You are a prisoner?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The loss of liberty
No doubt sir, is a heavy and sharp burden
To them that feel it truly: but your servant,
Your humble handmaid, never felt that rigor,
Thanks to that noble will: no want, no hunger,
(Companions still to slaves) no violence,
Nor any unbeseeming act, we start at,
Have I yet met with; all content and goodness,
Civility, and sweetness of behaviour
Dwell round about me; therefore, worthy master,
I cannot say I grieve my liberty.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Do not you fancy me too cold a soldier,
Too obstinate an enemy to youth,
That had so fair a jewel in my cabinet,
And in so long a time, would ne'er look on it?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What can she say now?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sure I desired to see ye,
And with a longing wish.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There's all her virtue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pursued that full desire to give ye thanks sir,
The only sacrifice I have left, and service
For all the virtuous care you have kept me safe with.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: She holds well yet.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The pretty fool, speaks finely:
Come sit down here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O sir, 'tis most unseemly.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'll have it so: fit close; now tell me truly,
Did you ere love yet?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My years will answer that sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And did you then love truly?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So I thought sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Can ye love me so?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Now!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: With all my duty;
I were unworthy of those favours else,
You daily shower upon me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What thinkst thou of me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I think ye are a truly worthy gentleman,
A pattern, and a pride to the age ye live in,
Sweet as the commendations all men give ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A pretty flattering rogue; dare ye kiss that sweet man
Ye speak to sweetly of? Come,

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Farewell virtue.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What hast thou go between thy lips? kiss once more.
Sure thou hast a spell there.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: More than ere I knew sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: All hopes go now.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I must tell you a thing in your ear, and you must hear me,
And hear me willingly, and grant me so too,
'Twill not be worth my asking else.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It must be
A very hard thing fir, and from my power,
I shall deny your goodness.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis a good wench; I must lie with ye lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis something strange:
For yet in all my life I knew no bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You will quickly find that knowledge.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To what end sir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Art thou so innocent, thou canst not guess at it?
Did thy dreams never direct thee?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I'faith none yet sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'll tell thee then: I would meet thy youth and pleasure;
Give thee my youth for that, by heaven she fires me,
And teach thy fair white arms, like wanton Ives,
A thousand new embraces,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is that all sir?
And say I should try, may not we lie quietly?
Upon my conscience I could.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That's as we make it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Grant that, that likes ye best, what would ye do then?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What would I do? certainly, I am no baby,
Nor brought up for a nun; hark in thine ear.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Fie, fie, sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I would get a brave boy on thee,
A warlike boy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sure we shall get ill Christians.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: We'll mend 'em in the breeding then.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sweet master.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Never belief in woman come near me more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My best and noblest sir, if a poor virgin,
(For yet by — I am so) should change so far
(Seeing your excellence, and able sweetness)
To forget herself, and slip into your bosom,
Or to your bed, out of a doting on ye,
Take it the best way; have you that cruel heart,
That murdering mind too?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes by my troth (Sweet) have I,
To lie with her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And do you think it well done?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That's as she'll think when 'tis done; come to bed wench,
For thou art so pretty, and so witty a companion,
We must not part tonight .

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Faith let me go sir,
And think better on't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'faith thou shalt not;
I warrant thee I'll think on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have heard 'em say here,
You are a maid too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I am sure I am, wench,
If that will please thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have seen a wonder,
And would you lose that for a little wantonness,
(Consider my sweet master, like a man, now,)
For a few honeyed kisses, sleight embraces,
That glory of your youth, that crown of sweetness?
Can ye deliver that unvalued treasure?
Would ye forsake, to seek your own dishonour,
What gone, no age recovers, nor repentance?
To a poor stranger?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Hold there again, thou art perfect.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: I know you do but try me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And I know
I'll try you a great deal further: prithee to bed;
I love thee, and so well: come kiss me once more;
Is a maidenhead ill bestowed of me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's this sir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why, 'tis the badge (My sweet) of that holy order
I shortly must receive, the cross of Malta.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What virtue has it?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: All that we call virtuous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Who gave it first?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: He that gave all, to save us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why then 'tis holy too?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: True sign of holiness,
The badge of all his soldiers that profess him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The badge of all his soldiers that profess him,
Can save in dangers?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In troubles comfort?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You say true, sweet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In sickness, restore health?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: All this it can do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Preserve from evils, that afflict our frailties.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I hope she will be christian: all these truly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why are you sick then, sick to death with lust?
In danger to be lost? no holy thought,
Ln all that heart, nothing but wand'ring frailties
Wild as the wind, and blind as death or ignorance,
Inhabit there.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Forgive me heaven, she says true.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dare ye profess that badge, profane that goodness?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Thou hast redeemed thyself again, most rarely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That holiness and truth ye make me wonder at?
Blast all the bounty heaven gives, that remembrance.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: O excellent woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Fling it from ye quickly,
If ye be thus resolved; I see a virtue
Appear in't like a sword, both edges flaming
That will consume ye, and your thoughts, to ashes,
Let them profess it that are pure, and noble,
Gentle, and just of thought, that build the cross,
Not those that break it, by — if ye touch me,
Even in the act, I'll make that cross, and curse ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You shall not (Fair) I did dissemble with ye,
And but to try your faith, I fashioned all this:
Yet something you provoked me: this fair cross,
By me (If he but please to help, first gave it)
Shall ne'er be worn upon a heart corrupted;
Go to your rest, my modest, honest servant,
My fair, and virtuous maid, and sleep secure there,
For when you suffer, I forget this sign here.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A man of men too: oh most perfect gentleman!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All sweet rest to your sir; I am half a christian,
The other half, I'll pray for; then for you, sir;

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This is the foulest play I'll show, good night, sweet.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: The sun's not set yet?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Would it were,
Never to rise again to light the world.
And yet, to what vain purpose do I wish it,
Since though I were environed with thick mists,
Black as Cimmerian darkness, or my crimes,
There is that here, upon which, as an anvil
Ten thousand hammers strike, and every spark
They force from it, to me's another sun
To light me to my shame?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Take hope, and comfort.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: They are aides indeed, but yet as far from me,
As I from being innocent: this cave fashioned
By provident nature, in this solid rock
To be a den for beasts, alone, receives me,
And having proved an enemy to mankind,
All humane helps forsake me.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: I'll ne'er leave you,
And wish you would call back that noble courage
That old invincible fortitude of yours
That used to shrink at nothing.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Then it did not.
But 'twas when I was honest; then in the height
Of all my happiness, of all my glories,
Of all delights, that made life precious to me,
I durst die Rocca; death itself then to me
Was nothing terrible, because I knew,
The fame of a good knight would ever live
Fresh on my memory; but since I fell
From my integrity, and dismissed those guards,
Those strong assurances of innocence,
That constancy fled from me, and what's worse,
Now I am loathsome to myself; and life
A burden to me, racked with sad remembrance
Of what I have done, and my present horrors
Unsufferable to me, tortured with despair
That I shall ne'er find mercy; hell about me,
Behind me, and before me, yet I dare not
Still fearing worse, put off my wretched being. Enter Abdella

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: To see this would deter a doubtful man
From mischievous intents, much more the practice
Of what is wicked: here's the Moor, look up sir,
Some ease may come from her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: New trouble rather,
And I expect it.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Who is this? Mountferrat?
Rise up for shame, and like a river dried up
With a long drought, from me, your bounteous sea
Receive those tides of comfort, that flow to you;
If ever I looked lovely, if desert
Could ever challenge welcome; if revenge,
And unexpected wreak, were ever pleasing
Or could endear the giver of such blessings,
All these I come adorned with, and as due
Make challenge of those so long wished embraces
Which you (Unkind) have hitherto denied me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Why, what have you done for me?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Made Gomera
As truly miserable, as you thought him happy,
Could you wish more?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As if his sickness could
Recover me; the injuries I received
Were Oriana's.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: She has paid dear for them,
She's dead.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Dead: my hate could reach no further:
Taking advantage of her in a swoon,
Under pretence to give a cordial to her
I poisoned her: what stupid dulness is this?
What you should entertain with sacrifice,
Can you receive so coldly?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Bloody deeds
Are grateful offerings, pleasing to the devil,
And thou, in thy black shape, and blacker actions
Being hell's perfect character, art delighted
To do what I though infinitely wicked,
Tremble to hear: thou hast in this ta'en from me
All means to make amends with penitence,
To her wronged virtues, and despoiled me of
The poor remainder of that hope was left me,
For all I have already, or must suffer.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: I did it for the best.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: For thy worst ends,
And be assured, but that, I think to kill thee
Would but prevent, what thy despair must force thee
To do unto thyself, and so to add to
Thy most assured damnation, thou went dead now,
But get thee from my sight: and if lust of me
Did ever fire thee (Love, I cannot call it)
Leap down from those steep rocks, or take advantage
Of the next tree, to hang thyself, and then
I may laugh at it.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: In the mean time
I must be bold, to do so much for you, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mount,
sp.l: Why grinst thou, devil?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: That 'tis in my power,
To punish thy ingratitude; I made trial
But how you stood affected, and since I know
I am used only for a property,
I can, and will revenge it to the full.
For, understand, in thy contempt of me
Those hopes of Oriana, which I could
Have changed to certainties, are lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Why, lives she?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Yes, but never to Mountferrat,
Although it is in me, with as much ease
To give her freely up to thy possession,
As to remove this rush, which yet despair of,
For by my much wronged love, flattery, nor threats,
Tears, prayers, nor vows, shall ever win me to it:
So with my curse, I leave thee.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Prithee stay,
Thou know'st I dote on thee, and yet thou art
So peevish, and perverse, so apt to take
Trifles unkindly from me.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: To persuade me
To break my neck, to hang, then damn myself,
With you are trifles.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: 'T was my melancholy
That made me speak I know not what: forgive,
I will redeem my fault.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Believe him lady.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: A thousand times I will demand thy pardon,
And keep the reckoning on thy lips, with kisses.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: There's something else, that would prevail more with me.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Thou shalt have all thy wishes do but bless me
With means to satisfy my mad desires
For once in Oriana, and for ever
I am thine, only thine my best Abdella.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Were I assured of this, and that you would
Having enjoyed her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Any thing: make choice of
Thine own conditions.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Swear then, that performed.
(To free me from all doubts and fears hereafter)
To give me leave to kill her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: That our safety
Must of necessity urge us to.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Then know
It was not poison, but a sleeping potion
Which she received, yet of sufficient strength
So to bind up her senses, that no sign
Of life appeared in her, and thus thought dead
In her best habit, as the custom is
You know in Malta, with all ceremonies
She's buried in her family's monument,
In the temple of st. John; I'll bring you thither,
Thus, as you are disguised; some six hours hence
The potion will leave working.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Let us haste then. Discover tomb

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Be my good angel, guide me.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: But remember
You keep your oath.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As I desire to prosper
In what I undertake.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: I ask no more. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Here sir, I have got the key, I borrowed it
Of him that keeps the church, the door is open.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Look to the horses then, and please the fellow.
After a few devotions, I'll retire.
Be not far off, there may be some use of ye,
Give me the light: come friend, a few good prayers
Were not bestowed in vain now, even from you sir.
Men that are bred in blood, have no way left 'em,
No bath, no purge, no time to wear it out
Or wash it off, but penitence, and prayer:
I am to take the order, and my youth
Loaden I must confess with many follies,
Circled and bound about with sins as many
As in the house of memory live figures.
My heart I'll open now, my faults confess.
And rise a new man, heaven I hope, to a new life.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I have no great devotion, at this instant,
But for a prayer or two, I will not out sir,
Hold up your finger, when you have prayed enough.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Go you to that end.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I shall ne'er pray alone sure,
sp.p: I have been so used to answer the clerk: would I had a cushion, for I shall ne'er make a good hermit, and knee till my knees are horn, these stones are plaguy hard where shall I begin now? for if I do not observe a method, I shall be out presently.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: O, o.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: What's that sir? did ye hear?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ha; to your prayers.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: 'Twas hereabouts , t'has put me clean awry now,
I shall ne'er get in again, ha, by land,
And water, all children, and all women,
I there it was I left.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: O, o.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Never tell me sir,
Here's something got amongst us.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I heard a groan:
A dismal one, — Ori. O, oh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Here, 'tis here sir, 'tis here sir;
A devil in the wall.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis some illusion
To fright us from devotion — Ori. O, o.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Why 'tis here,
The spirit of a huntsman choked with butter,
Here's a new tomb, new trickments too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: For certain,
This has not been three days here.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: And a tablet
With rhymes upon't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I prithee read 'em Norandine.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: An epi — and epi — taff. I think 'tis, I 'tis taff, an epitaph.
Upon the most excel, excel — lent — and.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou canst not read.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I have spoilt mine eyes with gunpowder,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: An epitaph upon the most virtuous, and excellent lady
The honour of chastity, Oriana.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: The grand master's sister: how a devil came she here?
When slipped she out oth' way, the stone's but half upon her.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis is a sudden change: certain the mischief
Mountferrat offered to her broke her heartstrings.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Would he were here, I would be the clerk myself,
And by this little light. I would bury him alive here,
Here's no lamenting now.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: O, o.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: There 'tis.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sure from the monument, the very stone groans for her.
O, dear lady: blessing of women, virtue of thy sex;
How art thou set for ever, how stolen from us.
Babbling, and prating now converse with women.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Sir it rises, it looks up. She rises up.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Heaven bless us.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: It is in woman's clothes, it rises higher.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It looks about, and wonders, sure she lives sir.
'Tis she, 'tis Oriana, 'tis that lady.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Shall I go to her?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Where am I!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Stand still.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What place is this?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She is as live as I am.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What sinell of earth, and rotten bones, what dark place.
Lord, whither am I carried?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: How she stares,
And sets her eyes upon him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How is't dear lady?
Do you know me, how she shakes?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: You are a man.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A man that honours you.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: A cruel man,
Ye are all cruel: are you in your grave too?
For there's no trusting cruel man, above ground.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: By'rlady, that goes hard.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: To do your service
And to restore ye to the joys you were in.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I was in joys indeed, and hope —

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: She sinks again
Again she is gone; she is gone: gone as a shadow,
She sinks for ever, friend.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She is cold now,
She is certainly departed, I must cry too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The blessed angels guide thee: put the stone too,
Beauty thou art gone to dust, goodness to ashes.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pray take it well: we must all have our hours sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ay, thus we are; and all our painted glory,
A bubble that a boy blows in toth' air,
And there it breaks.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I am glad ye saved her honour yet.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Would I had saved her life now too: o heaven
For such a blessing, such a timely blessing
Oh friend, what dear content 't would be, what story
To keep my name from worms?

sp.speaker: Oria
sp.l: O, o.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She lives again,
'Twas but a trance.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pray ye call my man in presently
Help with the stone first, o she stirs again.
O call my man away.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I fly, I fly sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Upon my knees oh heaven, oh heaven I thank thee. The living heat steals into every member; En. Colonn. And come help the coffin out, softly, and suddenly norand. Where is the clerk?.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Drunk above, he is sure sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sirrah, you must be secret.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: As your soul sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Softly good friend, take her into your arms.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Put in the crust again.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And bring her out there when I am a horseback
My man, and I will tenderly conduct her
Unto the fort; slay you, and watch what issue,
And what inquiry's for the body.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And when ye have done, come back to me.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Softly, o softly.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: She grows warmer still sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What shall I do with 'Key?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou canst not stir now,
Leave it ith' door: go get the horses ready.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.p: The door's already open, the key in it. En. Rocca Mountferrat Abdella. With a dark lantern.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: What were those passed by?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Some scout of soldiers, I think.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: It may be well so, for I saw their horses,
They saw not us I hope.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: No, no, we were close,
Beside they were far off.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: What time of night is't?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Much about twelve I think.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Let me go in first
For by the leaving open of the door here
There may be somebody in the church: give me the lantern.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: You'll love me now I hope.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Make that good to me
Your promise is engaged for.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Why she is there
Ready prepared, and much about this time
Life will look up again.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Come in all's sure,
Not a foot stirring, nor a tongue.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Heaven bless me,
I never entered with such unholy thoughts
This place before.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Ye are a fearful fool,
If men have appetites allowed 'em,
And warm desires, are there not ends too for 'em?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Whether shall we carry her?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Why, to the bark, sir,
I have provided one already waits us
The wind stands wondtrous fair too for our passage.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: And there, when you've enjoyed her, for ye have that liberty
Let me alone to send her to feed fishes,
I'll no more sighs for her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Where is the monument?
Thou art sure she will awake about this time?

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Most sure, if she be not knocked oth' head: give me the lantern,
Here 'tis, how is this, the stone off?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Ay, and nothing
Within the monument, that's worse, nobody
I am sure of that, nor sign of any here,
But an empty coffin.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: No lady.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: No, nor lord sir,
This pie has been cut up before.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Either the devil
Must do these tricks —

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Or thou, damned one, worse;
Thou black swollen pitchy cloud, of all my afflictions:
Thou night hag, gotten when the bright moon suffered
Thou hell itself confined in flesh: what trick now?
Tell me, and tell me quickly what thy mischief
Has done with her, and to what end, and whether
Thou hast removed her body, or by this holy place
This sword shall cut thee into thousand pieces.
A thousand thousand, strew thee o'er the temple
A sacrifice to thy black sire, the devil.

sp.speaker: Rod
sp.l: Tell him, you see he's angry.

sp.speaker: Abd.
sp.l: Let him burst,
Neither his sword, nor anger do I shake at,
Nor will yield to feed his poor suspicions,
His idle jealousies, and mad dogs hears
One thought against myself: ye have done a brave deed
A manly, and a valiant piece of service
When ye have killed me; reckon't amongst your battles:
I am sorry ye are so poor, so weak a gentleman
Able to stand no fortune: I dispose of her?
My mischief make her away? A likely project,
I must play booty against myself, if any thing cross ye
I am the devil, and the devil's heir,
All plagues, all mischiefs.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Will I ye leave and do yet?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I have done too much,
For, far too much for such a thankless fellow,
If I be devil, you created me,
I never knew those arts, nor bloody practises
(— of your cunning heart, that mine of mischief)
Before your flatteries won 'em into me,
Here did I leave her, leave her with that certainty
About this hour to wake again.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Where is she?
This is the last demand.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Did I now know it,
And were I sure, this were my latest minute
I would not tell thee: strike, and then I'll curse thee:

sp.speaker: Rocca
sp.l: I see a light, stand close, and leave your angers.
We all miscarry else. Enter Gomera, page with torch.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I am now careless,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Peace, prithee peace, sweet, peace, all friends,

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Stand close then.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Wait there boy, with the light, till I call to thee,
In darkness was my soul and senses clouded
When my fair jewel fell, the night of jealousy,
In all her blackness drawn about my judgement:
No light was let into me: to distinguish
Betwixt my sudden anger and her honour,
A blind sad pilgrimage shall be my penance,
No comfort of the day will I look up at:
Far darker than my jealous ignorance
Each place of my abode shall do my: prayers
No ceremonious lights shall set off more;
Bright arms, and all that carry lustre, life,
Society, and solace, I forsake ye.
And were it not once more to see her beauties
(For in her bed of death, she must be sweet still,)
And on her cold sad lips seal my repentance;
Thou child of heaven, fair light I could not miss thee.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: I know the tongue, would I were out again I have done him too much wrong to look upon him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: There is no shifting now, boldness, and confidence
Must carry it now away: he is but one neither,
Naked as you are, of a strength far under

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: But he has a cause above me,

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: That's as you handle it.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Peace: he may go again, and never see us.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: I feel I weep apace, but where's the flood,
The torrent of my tears, to drown my fault in,
I would I could now like a loaden cloud
Begotten in the moist South, drop to nothing
Give me the torch, boy.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Now he must discover us.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: He has already, never hide your head
Be bold, and brave, if we must die together.

sp.speaker: Gom:
sp.l: Who's there? what friend to sorrow? The tomb wide open
The stone off too? the body gone, by —
Look to the door boy: keep it fast, who are ye?
What sacrilegious villains? false Mountferrat,
The wolf to honour, has thy hellish hunger,
Brought thee to tear the body out oth' tomb too?
Has thy foul mind so far wrought on thee? ha,
Are you there too? nay, than I spy a villainy
I never dreamt of yet, thou sinful usher
Bred from that rottenness, thou bawd to mischief,
Do you blush through all your blackness? will not that hide it?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: You are well met, with your dam, sir,
Art thou a knight? did ever on that sword,
The Christian cause sit nobly? could that hand fight,
Guided by fame, and fortune? that heart inflame thee,
With virtuous fires of valour, to fall off,
Fall off so suddenly, and with such foulness,
As the false angels did, from all their glory?
Thou art no knight, honour thou never heardest of,
Nor brave desires could ever build in that breast,
Treason, and tainted thoughts, are all the gods
Thou worshippest, all the strength thou hadst: and fortune;
Thou didst things out of fear, and false heart, villain
Out of close traps and treacheries, they have raised thee.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Thou ravest old man.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Before thou gettest off from me,
Hadst thou the glory of thy first fights on thee
Which thou hast basely lost, thy noblest fortunes,
And in their greatest lustres, I would make thee
Before we part, confess, nay, kneel, and do it,
Nay, crying kneel, coldly for mercy, crying:
Thou art the recreant'st rogue, time ever nourished,
Thou art a dog, I will make thee swear, a dog staved,
A mangy cur-dog; do you creep behind the altar?
Look how it sweats, to shelter such a rascal;
First, with thy venomous tooth infect her chaste life,
And then not dare to do; next, rob her rest,
Steal her dead body out oth' grave.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I have not.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Prithee come out, this is no place to quarrel in, valiant Mountferrat come,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I will not stir.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Thou hast thy sword about thee,
That good sword, that never failed thee: prithee come,
We'll have but five strokes for it, on, on boy,
Here's one would fain be acquainted with thee,
Would wondrous fain cleave that calves-head of yours sir,
Come, prithee let's dispatch, the moon shines finely:
Prithee be killed by me, thou wilt be hanged else,
But it may be, thou longest to be hanged.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Out with him, sir,
You shall have my sword too: when he's dispatched once
We have the world before us.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Wilt thou walk fellow,
I never knew a rogue, hang arseward so,
And such a desperate knave too.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Pray go with him,
Something I'll promise too,

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: You would be killed then?
No remedy; I see,

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: If thou dar'st do it?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Yes, now I dare; lead out, I'll follow presently under the mount I'll meet ye.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Go before me,
He have ye in a string too.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As I am a gentleman,
And by this holy place, I will not fail thee,
Fear not, thou shalt be killed, take my word for it
I will not fail.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: If thou seap'st thou hast cats luck,
The mount?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: The same: make haste, I am there before else.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Go get ye home; now if he scape I am coward.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Well, now I am resolved, and he shall find it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How is it with the lady?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, as well
As it can be with one, who feeling knows now
What is the curse the divine justice laid
On the first sinful woman.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Is she in travel?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yes sir; and yet the troubles of her mind
Afflict her more, then what her body suffers,
For in the extremity of her pain, she cries out,
Why am I here? Where is my lord Gomera,
Then sometimes names Miranda, and then sighs,
As if to speak, what questionless she loves well,
If heard, might do her injury.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Heaven's sweet mercy
Look gently on her,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Prithee tell her, my prayers
Are present with her, and good wench provide
That she want nothing: what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Lucinda? there's a prosperous omen in it,
Bea Lucina to her, and bring word
That she is safe delivered of her burden,
And thy rewards thy liberty: come Collonna,
We will go see how th' engineer has mounted
The cannon the great master sent, be careful.
To view the works, and learn the discipline
That is used here: I am to leave the world
And for your service, which I have found faithful.
The charge that's mine, if I have any power
Hereafter may concern you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I still find
A noble master in you,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis but justice,
sp.p: Thou dost deserve it in thy care, and duty. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Gomera, Mountferrat, Rocca, Abdella, with a pistol.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.p: Here's even ground, I'll stir no foot beyond it, before I have thy head.

sp.speaker: Maunt
sp.l: Draw Rocca.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Coward,
Hath inward guilt, robbed thee as well of courage
As honesty? that without odds thou dar'st not
Answer a single enemy?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: All advantage
That I can take, expect.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: We know you are valiant,
Nor do we purpose to make further trial
Of what you can do now: but to dispatch you.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: And therefore fight, and pray together.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Villains,
Whose baseness, all disgraceful words made one,
Cannot express; so strong is the good cause
That seconds me, that you shall feel, with horror
To your proud hopes, what strength is in that arm,
Though old, that holds a sword made sharp by justice.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: You come then here, to prate?Fight.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Help Rocca, now,
Or I am lost forever; how comes this?
Are villainy, and weakness twines?

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: I am gone too.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: You shall not scape me, wretches,

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I must do it,
All will go wrong else.Shoots him

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Treacherous bloody woman,
What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Done a poor woman's part,
And in an instant, what these men so long
Stood fooling for.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: This aid was unexpected,
I kiss thee for't,

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: His right arms only shot,
And that compelled him to forsake his sword,
He's else unwounded.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Forbear.
Yet do not hope 'tis with intent to save thee.
But that thou mayst live to thy farther torment
To see who triumphs over thee: come Mountferrat,
Here join thy foot to mine, and let our hearts
Meet with our hands, the contract that is made
And cemented with blood, as this of ours is,
Is a more holy sanction, and much surer,
Than all the superstitious ceremoniesEnter Norandine.
You Christians use.

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Betrayed again?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: By the report it made, and by the wind
The pistol was discharged here.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Norandine,
As ever thou lovest valour, or wear'st arms
To punish baseness, show it.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: O the devil,
Gomera wounded, and my brach black beauty
An actor in it?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: If thou strikest, I'll shoot thee.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: How? fright me with your potgun? what art thou?
Good heaven, the rogue, the traitor rogue Mountferrat
To swinge the nest of you, is a sport unlooked for,
Hells — consume you.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: As thou art a man;
I am wounded, give me time to answer thee.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Dared thou urge this? this hand can hold a sword yet.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Well done: to see this villain, makes my hurts
Bleed fresh again, but had I not a bone whole,
In such a cause I should do thus, thus rascals. Enter corporal and watch.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Disarm them, and shoot any that resists.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Hold corporal; I am Gomera,

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: 'Tis well yet, that once in an age you can
Remember what you watch for; I had thought
You had again been making out your parties
For sucking pigs.
'Tis well:

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: As you will answer
The contrary with your lives, see these forth coming.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: That we shall do.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: You bleed a pace: good soldiers
Go help him to a surgeon,

sp.speaker: Roc.
sp.l: Dare the worst,
And suffer like yourself.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: From me learn courage.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Now for Miranda, this news will be to him
As welcome, as 'tis unexpected: corporal,
There's something for thy care tonight : my horse there.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: How does my boy?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O, wondrous lusty, madam,
A little knight already: you shall live
To see him toss a Turk.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Gentle Lucinda,
Much must I thank thee for thy care, and service.
And may I grow but strong to see Valetta,Enter Miranda, Norandine, Collonna.
My husband, and my brother, thou shalt find
I will not barely thank thee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Look captain, we must ride away this morning
The auberge sits today, and the great master
Writes plainly, I must or deliver in
(The year expired) my probation weed,
Or take the cloak: you likewise Norandine
For your full service, and your last assistance
In false Mountferrat's apprehension
Are here commanded to associate me; my twin in this high honour.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: I'll none on't: do they think to bind me to live chaste, sober, and temperately, all days of my life? they may as soon tie an Englishman to live so: I shall be a sweet Dane, a sweet captain, go up and down drinking small beer, and swearing odds neagues; no I'll live a squire at arms still, and do thou so too; and thou beest wise: I have found the mystery now, why the gentlemen wear but three bars of the cross, and the knights the whole one.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why captain?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Marry sir, to put us in remembrance, we are but three quarters crossed in our licence, and pleasures: but the poor knights crossed altogether; the brothers at arms, may yet meet with their sisters at arms, now and then, in brotherly love; but the poor knights cannot get a lady for love, nor money: 'tis not so in other countries I wis, pray haste you, for I'll along, and see what will come on't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Collonna, provide straight, all necessaries
For this remove, the litter for the lady,
And let Lucinda bear her company,
You shall attend on me.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: With all my dutiesExit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How fare you, gracious mistress?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: O Miranda.
You pleased to honour me with that fair title
When I was free, and could dispose myself;
But now, no smile, no word, no look, no touch
Can I impart to any, but as theft
From my Gomera; and who dares accept,
Is an usurper.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Leave us; I have touched thee,
(Thou fairer virtue, then thou'rt beautiful)
Hold but this test, so rich an one was neverAltar ready, tapers and book
Tried by the hand of man, on the vast earth:
Sit brightest Oriana, is it sin
Still to profess I love you, still to vow
I shall do ever? heaven my witness be,
'Tis not your eye, your cheek, your tongue, no part
That superficially doth snare young men,
Which has caught me; read over in your thoughts
The story that this man hath made of you,
And think upon his merit.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Only thought
Can comprehend it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And can you be so
Cruel, thankless, to destroy his youth
That saved your honour, gave you double life?
Your own, and your fair infants? that when fortune
(The blind foe to all beauty, that is good,)
Bandied you from one hazard to another,
Was even heaven's messenger, by providence
Called to the temple, to receive you there,
Into these arms, to give ease to your throws,
As if't had thundered; take thy due Miranda,
For she was thine; gomera's jealousy
Struck death unto thy heart; to him be dead,
And live to me, that gave thee second life:
Let me but now enjoy thee: o regard
The torturing fires of my affections.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: O master them, Miranda, as I mine;
Who follows his desires, such tyrants serves
As will oppress him, insupportably.
My flames, Miranda, rise as high as thine,
For I did love thee 'fore my marriage,
Yet would I now consent, or could I think
Thou wert in earnest, (Which by all the souls
That have (For chastity) been sanctified
I cannot) in a moment I do know
Thou'dst call fair temperance up to rule thy blood,
Thy eye was ever chaste, thy countenance too honest,
And all thy wooings was like maiden's talk;
Who yields unto pleasures, and to lust
Is a poor captive, that in golden fetters
(And precious (As he thinks) but holding gyves)
Frets out his life.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Find such another woman,
And take her for his labour, any man:

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I was not worthy of thee, at my best,
Heaven knew I was not, I had had thee else;
Much less now gentle sir; Miranda's deeds
Have been as white, as Oriana's fame,
From the beginning, to this point of time,
And shall we now begin to stain both thus?
Think on the legend which we two shall breed
Continuing as we are, for chastest dames
And boldest soldiers to peruse and read,
I and read through, free from any act
To cause the modest cast the book away,
And the most honoured captain fold it up.

sp.speaker: Mir;
sp.l: Fairest; let go my hand: my pulse beats thick,
And my moved blood rides high in every vain,
Lord of thyself now, soldier, and ever:
I would not for Aleppo, this frail bark,
This bark of flesh, no better fleeres-man had
Then has Mountferrat's: may you kiss me, lady?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: No; though't be no essential injury,
It is a circumstance due to my lord,
To none else: and my dearest friend, if hands
Playing together, kindle heat in you,
What may the game at lips provoke unto?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O what a tongue is here? whilst she doth teach
My heart to hate my fond unlawful love,
She talks me more in love, with love to her,
My fires she quencheth with her arguments,
But as she breathes 'em, they blow fresher fires.
Sir further: now my flame cools; husband, wife,
There is some holy mystery in those names
That sure the unmarried cannot understand.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Now thou art straight, and dost enamour me,
So far behind a carnal earthly love;
My very soul dotes on thee, and my spirits
Do embrace thine, my mind doth thy mind kiss,
And in this pure conjunction we enjoy
A heavenlier pleasure than if bodies met:
This, this is perfect love, the other short,
Yet languishing fruition, every swain
And sweating groom may clasp, but ours refined
Two in ten ages cannot reach unto;
Nor is our spiritual love, a barren joy,
For mark what blessed issue we'll beget,
Dearer than children to posterity,
A great example to men's continence,
And women's chastity, that is a child
More fair, and comfortable, than any heir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If all wives were but such, lust would not find
One corner to inhabit, sin would be
So strange, remission superfluous:
But one petition, I have done.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What (Sweet?).

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: To call me lord, if the hard hand of death seize on Gomera first.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: O, much too worthy;
How much you undervalue your own price,
To give your unbought self, for a poor woman,
That has been once sold, used, and lost her show?
I am a garment worn, a vessel cracked,
A zone untied, a lily trod upon,
A fragrant flower cropped by another's hand,
My colour sullied, and my odour changed,
If when I was new blossomed, I did fear
Myself unworthy of Miranda's spring:
Thus overblown, and seeded, I am rather
Fit to adorn his chimney, than his bed.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Rise miracle: save Malta, with thy virtue,
If words could make me proud, how has she spoke,
Yet I will try her to the very block:
Hard-hearted, and uncivil Oriana,
Ingrateful payer of my industries,
That with a soft painted hypocrisy
Cozenest, and geerest my perturbation,
Expect a witty, and a fell revenge:
My comfort is, all men will think thee false,
Beside thy husband having been thus longEnter Nor. Collonna and Lucinda with a child.
(On this occasion) in my fort, and power.
I'll hear no more words: captain, let's away
With all care see to her: and you Lucinda
Attend her diligently: she is a wonder.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Have you found she was well delivered:
What, had she a good midwife, is all well?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You are merry Norandine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why weep you, lady?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Take the poor babe along.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Madam 'tis here.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Dissembling death, why didst thou let me live
To see this change, my greatest cause to grieve? Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Astorius, castriot, Valetta, Gomera, Synnet: knights, 2 Bishops, Mountferrat, guarded by corporal and soldiers, Abdella, a gentleman with a cloak, sword, and spurs: Gomara.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A tender husband hast thou showed thyself
My dearest brother, and thy memory
After my life, in brazen characters,
Shall monumentally be registered
To ages consequent, till times running hand,
Beats back the world to undistinguished chaos,
And on the top of that thy name shall stand
Fresh, and without decay.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: O honoured sir!
If hope of this, or any bliss to come
Could lift my load of grief off from my soul,
Or expiate the trespass 'gainst my wife,
That in one hours suspicion I begat,
I might be won to be a man again,
And fare like other husbands, sleep and eat,
Laugh, and forget my pleasing penitence;
But till old nature can make such a wife
Again, I vow never to resume the order
And habits, that to men are necessary,
All breath I'll spend in sighs, all sound in groans,
And know no company but my wasting moans.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: This will be wilful murder on yourself,
Nor like a christian do you bear the chance
Which th'inscrutable will of heaven admits.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: What would you have my weakness do, that
Suffered itself thus to be practised on,
By a damned hellhound, and his agent dam,
The impious midwife to obortive births,
And cruel instrument to his decrees?
By forgery they first assailed her life,
Heaven playing with us yet, in that, he wrought
My dearest friend, the servant to her virtue
To combat me, against his mistress truth.
That yet effectless, this enchanting witch,
Bred baneful jealousy against my lady,
My most immaculate lady, which seized on her
Almost to death: o yet! not yet content,
She in my hand put (To restore her life
As I imagined) what did execute
Their devilish malice, farther, great with child,
Was this poor innocent, that too was lost,
They doubled death upon her, not staying there,
They have done violence unto her tomb,
Not granting rest unto her in the grave:
I wish Miranda had enjoyed my prize;
For sure I'm punished for usurping her,
O what a tiger is resisted lust?
How it doth forage all?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Part of this tale
I grant you true; but 'twas not poison given her.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: I would it had, we had been far enough,
If we had been so wise, and had not now
Stood curtsying for your mercies here.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: Beside,
What is become oth' body? we know not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Peace impudents,
And dear Gomera practise patience
As I myself must, by some means at last
We shall dissolve this riddle.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Wherefore comes
This villain in the festival array,
As if he triumphed for his treachery?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: That is by our appointment: give us leave,
You shall know why a non. Enter Miranda, Norandine, Collona.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: One of the escort.

sp.speaker: Esg.
sp.l: The gentlemen are come,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Truyce than a while
With our sad thoughts; what are you both resolved?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Not I my lord: your down right captain still
I'll live, and serve you, not that altogether
I want compunction of conscience,
I have enough to save me, and that's all,
Bar me from drink, and drabs, e'en hang me too,
You must e'en make your captain's capons first,
I have too much flesh for this spiritual knighthood,
And therefore do desire forbearance, sir,
Till I am older, or more mortified,
I am too sound yet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What say you Miranda?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: With all pure zeal to heaven, duty to you,
I come to undergo it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Proceed toth' ceremony.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Before you match with this bright honoured title,
Admired Miranda, pardon what in thought
I ever did transgress against your virtue,
And may you find more joy with your new bride
Then poor Gomera ere in joyed with his.
But 'twas mine own crime, and I suffer for't:
Long wear your dignity, and worthily,
Whilst I obscurely in some corner vanish,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Have stronger thoughts, and better, first I crave
According to the order of the court
I may dispose my captives, and the fort,
That with a clean and purified heart
The fittiler I may endue my robe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: 'Tis granted. Enter Oriana veiled, ladies, Lucinda, child.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Bring the captives. To your charge
And staid tuition my most noble friend;
I then commend this lady; start not off
A fairer, and a chaster never lived;
By her own choice you are her guardian,
For telling her I was to leave my fort,
And to abandon quite all worldly cares.
Her own request was, to Gomera's hands
She might be given in custody, for she'd heard
He was a gentleman wise, and temperate,
Full of humanity to womankind,
And cause he had been married knew the better
How to entreat a lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What country woman is she?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Born a Greek.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Gomera, 'twill be barbarous to deny
A lady, that unto your refuge flies,
And seeks to shroud her under virtue's wing.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Excuse me noble sir; o think me not
So dull a devil, to forget the loss
Of such a matchless wife as I possessed,
And ever to endure the sight of woman:
Were she the abstract of her sex for form,
The only warehouse of perfection,
Where there no rose, nor lily but her cheek,
No music but her tongue; virtue but hers;
She must not rest near me, my vow is graven,
Here in my heart, irrevocably breathed
And when I break it,

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: This is rudeness Spaniard,
Unseasonably you play the Timonist,
Put on a disposition is not yours,
Which neither fits you, nor becomes you.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: We cannot force you but we would persuade.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Beseech you sir, no more I am resolved
To forsake Malta, tread a pilgrimage
To fair Jerusalem, for my lady's soul,
And will not be diverted.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You must bear
This child along 'We then.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: What child?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay then Gomera, thou art injurious,
This child is thine, and this rejected lady
Thou hast as often known, as thine own wife,
And this I'll make good on thee, with my sword.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Thou durst as well blaspheme: if such a scandal
(I crave the rights due to a gentleman)
Women unveil.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Will you refuse me yet?

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: My wife!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My sister!

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Somebody , thank heaven
I cannot speak.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All praise be ever given:

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: This saves our lives, yet would she had been dead;
The very sight of her afflicts me more
Than fear of punishment, or my disgrace.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How came you to the temple?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, to do
My poor devotions, and to offer thanks
For scaping a temptation ne'er performed
With this fair virgin. I restore a wife
Earth cannot parallel: and busy nature
If thou wilt still make women, but remember
To work 'em by this sampler; take heed sir,
Henceforth you never doubt sir.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: When I do
Death take me suddenly.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: To increase your happiness
To your best wife, take this addition.

sp.speaker: Gom.
sp.l: Alack, my poor knave.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The confession
The Moor made 't seems was truth.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Marry was it sir; the only truth that ever issued out of hell, which her black jaws resemble; a plague of your bacon-face, you must be giving drinks with a vengeance; ah thou branded bitch: d'ye stare, goggles, I hope to make winter boots of thy hide yet, she fears not damning: hell fire cannot parch her blacker than she is: d'ye grin, chimney sweeper.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: What is't Miranda?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That you would please Lucinda might attend you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: That suit sir, I consent not to.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My husband?
My dearest Angelo?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: More liggam bobs; is not this the fellow that swom
Like a duck to th'shore in our sea-service?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The very same, do not you know me now sir,
My name is Angelo, though Colonna veiled it,
Your countryman, and kinsman born in Florence,
Who from the neighbour island here of Goza
Was captive lead, in that unfortunate day
When the Turk bore with him three thousand souls;
Since in Constantinople have I lived
Where I beheld this Turkish damosel first.
A tedious suitor was I for her love,
And pitying such a beauteous case should hide
A soul profaned with infidelity,
I laboured her conversion with my love,
And doubly won her, to fair faith her soul
She first betrothed, and then her faith to me,
But fearful there to consummate this contract
We fled, and in that flight were ta'en again
By those same galleys, fore Valletta fought.
Since in your service I attended her,
Where, what I saw, and heard, hath joyed me more
Than all my past afflictions grieved before.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Wonders crown wonders: take thy wife Miranda.
Be henceforth called our Malta's better angel,
And thou her evil Mountferrat.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: We'll call him cacodaemon, with his block gib there, his succuba, his devil's seed, his spawn of Phlegeton, that of my conscience was bred of the spume of Cocytus; do ye snarl you black jill? she looks lie the picture of America.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why stay we now.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This last petition to the court,
I may bequeath the keeping of my fort
To this my kinsman, towards the maintenance
Of him, and his fair virtuous wife; discreet,
Loyal, and valiant I dare give him you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You must not ask in vain, sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My best thanks
To you my noble cousin, and my service
To the whole court; may I deserve this bounty.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Proceed to th'ceremony, one of our escort
Degrade Mountferrat first

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.l: I will not sue
For mercy, 'twere in vain; fortune thy worst.Music

div.stage: An altar discovered, with tapers, and a book on it. The two Bishops stand on each side of it Mountferrat as the song is singing ascends up the altar.

sp.l: See see, the stain of honour, virtue's foe,
Of virgin's fair fames, the foul overthrow,
That broken hath his oath of chastity
Dishonoured much this holy dignity,
Off with his robe, expel him forth this place,
Whilst we rejoice, and sing at his disgrace.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Since by thy actions thou hast made thyself
Unworthy of that worthy sign thou wearest,
And of our sacred order, into which
For former virtues, we received thee first,
According to our statutes, ordinances,
For praise unto the good, a terror to
The bad, and an example to all men;
We here deprive thee of our habit, and
Declare thee unworthy our society,
From which we do expel thee, as a rotten
Corrupted, and contagious member.

sp.speaker: Esq.
sp.l: Using th'authority th'superior
Hath given unto me, I untie this knot,
And take from thee the pleasing yoke of heaven:
We take from off thy breast this holy cross,
Which thou hast made thy burden, not thy prop;
Thy spurs we spoil thee off, eleaving thy heels
Bare of thy honour, that have kicked against
Our orders precepts: next we reave thy sword,
And give thee armless to thy enemies,
For being foe to goodness, and to God,
Last, about thy stiff neck, we this halter hang,
And leave thee to the mercy of the court.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Invest Miranda.
Fair child of virtue, honour's bloom
That here with burning zeal dost come
With joy to ask the white cross cloak,
And yield unto this pleasing yoke
That being young, vows chastity,
And choosest wilful poverty;
As this flame mounts, so mount thy zeal, thy glory
Rise passed the stars, and fix in heaven thy story.

sp.speaker: 1. Bish.
sp.l: What crave you gentle sir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Humble admittance
To be a brother of the holy hospital
Of great Jerusalem.

sp.speaker: 2. Bish.
sp.l: Breath out your vow.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: To heaven and all the bench of saints above
Whose succour I implore t'enable me,
I vow henceforth a chaste life, not to enjoy
Any thing proper to myself; obedience
To my superiors, whom religion,
And heaven shall give me: ever to defend
The virtuous fame of ladies, and to oppugn
Even unto death the Christian enemy,
This do I vow to accomplish.

sp.speaker: Esq.
sp.l: Who can tell,
Has he made other vow, or promised marriage
To any one, or is in servitude?

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: He's free from all these.

sp.speaker: 1. Bish.
sp.l: Put on his spurs, and girt him with the sword,
The scourge of infidels, and tips of speed.
Buildest thy faith on this

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: On him that died
On such a sacred figure, for our sins.

sp.speaker: 2. Bish.
sp.l: Here, than we fix it on thy left side, for
Thy increase of faith, Christian defence, and service
To th'poor, and thus near to thy heart we plant it
That thou mayst love it even with all thy heart,
With thy right hand protect, preserve it whole,
For if thou fighting 'gainst heavens enemies
Shall fly away, abandoning the cross
The ensign of thy holy general,
With shame thou justly shalt be robbed of it
Chased from our company, and cut away
As an infectious putrified limb.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I ask no favour.

sp.speaker: 1 Bish.
sp.l: Then receive the yoke
Of him that makes it sweet, and light, in which
Thy soul find her eternal rest.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Most welcome.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Welcome, our noble brother.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Break up the court; Mountferrat, though your deeds
Conspiring 'gainst the lives of innocents
Hath forfeited your own, we will not stain
Our white cross with your blood: your doom is then
To marry this coagent of your mischiefs
Which done, we banish you the continent,
If either, after three days here be found
The hand of law, lays hold upon your lives.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: Away French stallion, now you have a Barbary mare of your own, go leap her, and engender young devillings.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We will find something, noble Norandine
To quit your merit: so to civil feasts,
According to our customs; and all pray
The dew of grace, bless our new knight today. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
